dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a balmy night in August, 1940. We open on the exteri of a swank Atlantic City nightclub, its dazzling facade illuminating a passing parade of hipsters, which stops li a freeze dance every time the club door opens and allows few bars of the music within to escape. It's the dream of every hipster that a party of fifteen will come out, keep the door open long enough perhaps to hear Ziggy Elman's entire trumpet solo on "Body and Soul'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, however, only a couple emerges, accompanied at best by a few diminished eighth notes. The man, elegantly dressed and refined in manner, is immediately recognizabl as Kid Twist, the bogus telegra h operator in "The Sting. On his arm is a statuesque blonde in clinging crepe. ey proceed to a cab and slide in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Twist leans forward to give instructions to the cabbie he fails to notice that the woman slides right out the ot side. He turns to find that her place has been taken by a huge hulk of a man who says nothing and stares straight ahead. Twist has seen that look before and moves to get o the way he cam in, only to find that there is now a thug the other side of him too. This one closes the door besid him and assumes the same pose as his friend. Twist realiz that he's in trouble. The cabbie pulls out with no word from the thugs. It doesn't matter. He knows better than they do where they're going. cut To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera moves in slowly on a man sitting alone in the dark, his head partially illuminated by the lights from t amusement park across the street. The only sound in the room comes from an unseen fan. The camera stops when we'r close enough to realize that the man is Doyle Lonnegan th gangster/mark of "The Sting." His eyes are set and far of

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: his face lost in thought. A knock is heard at the door, and Lonnegan jumps a bit as if someone had just snuck up on him. We hear a voice outside. It's Floyd, Lonnegan's right-hand man.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Doyle. Homer's downstairs. They made a clean snatch on Twist. You want us to dump him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, bring him here. I wanta see him first.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Okay. (noticing that there's no light coming under the door) You all right in there?

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Floyd walks on down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan slips back into his reverie. The camera starts t move in on him again. We burn into his eyes, which never blink despite the play of the neon across them. We hear: A sound montage of the replay of the last few minutes of "The Sting." 1. he voice of Lonnegan placing his half million dollar bet with great bravado, the call of a race in the b.g. 2. Kid Twist telling Lonnegan that he's bet incorrectly and will lose all his money. 3. Lonnegan trying frantically almost hysterically, to ge his money back from the cashier.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: 4. A fusilade of gun shots. 5. The voice of Detective Snyder urging Lonnegan out of t betting parlor. Again a knock is heard at the door.-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in. The door opens to reveal Twist and his two captors sil- houetted in the doorway. Lonnegan reaches out and turns on a light, and for the first time we are able to see the room. It looks like an expensive suite in any luxury hote except that the walls are covered with photographs, 8 x 1 blowups of every single man involved in the con of Lonneg some four years before. Prominently displayed above the others, like the leaders of some Eastern European politbu are shots of Gondroff and Hooker. Lonnegan allows Twist to take in the room before he speak Twist tries heard not to notice the photographs.

dialogues.speaker: _ LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: What do you think of my pictures Twist?

dialogues.speaker: TWIST
dialogues.text: My name's not Twist, and I don't know much about pictures.

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: You find yours yet?

dialogues.speaker: TWIST
dialogues.text: I don't know why a picture of me would be up there.

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (without taking his eyes off Twist On the wall to your left. Fourth one from the right. Between Curly Jackson and J.J. Singleton. Twist doesn't bother to look at the photograph. He knows it's there.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I coulda picked somebody else. I know where most of them are now. You just happened to be the closest.

dialogues.speaker: . TWIST
dialogues.text: I got no idea what you're talkin' about. I don't know any of these people....

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Four years ago, forty-seven months and six days to be exact, you helped them take me for half a million dol- lars. I should think you'd remember at. Look, you got me mixed up with somebody eise. I....

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (not even listening to Twist You played the telegraph operator, the guy who held up the race results. I'll never forget when you came in and told me I'd screwed ug the bet. Acting like it was the end of the world when inside you had to be jumping up and down. Gondorff musta been proud of you, Twist. I wish you could remember it. I had hoped it would have meant more to you to take a man like me. (offerin his hand T can only congratulate you on a job beautifully done. Lonnegan has attempted to deliver all this with a "no har feelings" attitude, but Twist is not fooled. He knows the will be no reprieve for him. He decides to go out like a champ .

dialogues.speaker: . TWIST
dialogues.text: Believe me, Lonnegan, it was the greatest day of my life. cut To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan and Floyd are sitting in a car looking out over the river to a warehouse on the other side. All the light are out in the warehouse, except for one on the second st at the top of a fifty-foot-long loading chute which runs from the second floor out over the water. It is normally used to convey cargo from the warehouse to freight barges

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 7
dialogues.text: below. lLonnegan and Floyd have their eyes glued to it, expecting something to happen there soon. Floyd, in par- ticular, seems to be anxious.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be here, Doyle. LONNEGAN us Get the word out that Macalinski put Kid Twist with the fishes. A body, feet encased in concrete, goes speeding down the loading chute and disappears below the surface of the bla water.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: That's one. With a gesture to Floyd, Lonnegan sits back grimly, and the car moves off. Main title and opening credits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Johnny Hooker washing himself in a makeshift shower that he's rigged up on the fire escape of his one~ room apartment. He uses old bed sheets for a curtain and his shower head consists of.a comb taped over the end of a garden hose which runs in through the window to a fauce on the small sink which occupies one corner of his totall undistinguished room. Hooker is obviously in an expansive mood, as he sings alo to the radio which he's hung on the landing above him. It's playing Helen Ward's version of "Goody Goody" with t Benny Goodman orchestra. His rinse water, meanwhile, drip through the grating of the fire escape to the pavement si floors below, watering several window boxes on the way. Hooker finishes up, and climbs back through his window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he's toweling off, the Eirie Kid enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hey, where's your suit?

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: I decided not to wear it. It'll just get dirty on the streetcar. HOOKER . What are you talking about? I rented a limousine.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: A limousine to go to the fights.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: we! re management now, Eirie. When you re the owner of an up and comin’ ight-heavy you don't show up on no streetcar.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: But our guy ain't even fightin' to- night. HOOKER — So what. You. want everybody to think we're small-time? Christ, the kid could be fightin' for the title inside a year, and you wanta show up on a goddamn trolley. bus woulda been better than that.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: We can't afford no bus, let a limo. Eirie notices a new pair of shoes on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Those your boats?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (proud as heli) How you like 'em, huh? Alligator Brazillian. Eirie looks them over like they're stale bread.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Hooker, I think we oughta skip the fight and see if we can’t get our- selves some pocket money. You know that dame I been tellin' ya about down at the Gardens? Weli I been studyin' her and I know we can take her for a bundle.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I don't like it, Eirie. I promised myself I was gonna go legit.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: You're just nervous, that's all. We're both a little rusty. We'll get over it once we get into the pitch. I know we still got our touch.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: It's bad enough goin' back on the grift, but connin' women. That's low, Eirie. We used to have a rule No poor people and no women.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: That was pregnant women, and this one ain't carryin' nothin' but dough. I tell ya, this dame is a thoroughbred, been in there two or three nights in a row, never talkin' to nobody but this oid broad that hangs around with her. She dresses like a champion, but I can tell she don't know her way around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : He I still don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: You like livin' in this pigpen better? You're already Bao o  months behind on the rent. e only rea~ son they ain't thrown you out is they couldn't get anybody else to live here.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Well you're the bookkeeper of the operation. Why don't you pay the damn rent?

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: I can't. You're overdrawn four grand at the bank. Eirie is interrupted by a knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker goes to answer it, half-dressed in a pair of socks

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: with knee on them. 10 suspenders and green shorts with the letters YMCA It's a Deliveryman with a tuxedo in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERYMAN
dialogues.text: Tuxedo for Mr. Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: That's me. (handing over a dollar bill) Here's a little somethin' for your trouble, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: __ DELIVERYMAN
dialogues.text: How about a little somethin' for the tux?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (easing the guy out the door} Bill me. Hooker turns back to Eirie and begins to putting on his t

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How can I be overdrawn? The last time I looked in there, I had _ eighty gees.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: That was two-and-a-half years ago, before you started buyin! prize fi inters, race horses, zinc mines every other goddamn thing. That stuff's gonna * Pay off, Eirie. It just takes time, at's all. In the world of investment, you gotta spend money to make money.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Hooker, I'm tellin' ya, if you don't do somethin' pretty fast, you're gonna start gettin' visits from the coppers Hooker knows that Eirie's right. People are gonna make so noise over four grand.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (resigned) All right eit call the girls and tell ‘em we'll be a little late.

dialogues.speaker: . EIRIE
dialogues.text: The girls?

dialogues.speaker: __ HOOKER
dialogues.text: You're gonna like these two, Eirie. They're hat checkers at the Rondella.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Christ, what am I gonna say to these babes? I don't know nothin' about ats. As Hooker dials his call, we: cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the great ballrooms of the era, in a class with th Roseland in New York and the Aragon and Trianon in Chicag Featuring an ocean of hardwood dance floor, divided here and there into inlets and bays by the arrangements of the tables, the Marine was a must play date for all the big swing bands of the forties. Not as elegant certainly as the supper clubs, but more exciting. The band's female vocalist is just getting into "You Turn The Tables On Me" as Hooker and Eirie enter the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: She's at table sixteen, on the left toward the front.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Hooker's eyes search the floor and finally come to rest o table sixteen. He's not quite ready for what he finds there. He had expected the Woman to be rich, but he hadn' expected her to be beautiful. Regal in bearing, she has the untouchable beauty of a Hedy Lamarr. The kind that turns passing strangers into employees. Hooker's first instinct is to turn around and go home. He has barely noticed the Older Woman to_her left, who is plainly dress and exudes a professional protectiveness toward her com- panion.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE .
dialogues.text: What'd I tell ya, huh? If she ain't loaded with jack, I don't know my own name. :

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: a

dialogues.speaker: _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: I don't feel right about this, Eirie. - I mean, she's with her mother and Eirie was taining a paper cut everything.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Look, this is no slight on her. She happens to be keepin’ company with some cash. It's not like you hate the dame. Someday when you're a millionaire, you can buy her a bracelet or somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hell, we don't even have any props with us. What are we gonna take her on? prepared for this. He takes out an envelope con- stack of fake money: and another one containing up the size of dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: I got the boodle and the stiff right here. All we gotta do is back it with some real green and we got everything we need. How muc! cash you got?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Fifteen bucks.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: I got twenty. We'll put mine on top and yours on the bottom. It ain't great, but it's good enough. Eirie puts the twenty on the top of the false bankroll, and the ten on the bottom. This is a

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Your problem is you're lettin' her looks go to your head. Since when have you ever gotten to first base with a dame like that? These society types think they're too good for . regular people. She wouldn't be seen outside a barnyard with either one of us. very telling point with Hooker. His heart be- gins to harden agains e Woman.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER .
dialogues.text: You're right, Eirie. That kinda babe gives me the pip. Shot through with new motivation, Hooker looks at the Woman like she's a barbell to be cleaned and jerked. He's a complete professional now. He takes off his watch and hands it to Eirie, then snatches a flower out of a vase and puts it in his lapel. We follow him as he makes his way over to table sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: AT TABLE SIXTEEN 13
dialogues.text: Hooker immediately affects the demeanor of an entrepeneur

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ladies. You haven't by chance seen a gold watch around here, have you? (through a thick French accent) No, I do not think so, Mr....

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Stewart. Charles Stewart. I'm the ’ manager here.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you, Mr. Stewart. I am Veronique LeFleur, and....

dialogues.speaker: OLDER WOMAN
dialogues.text: (interrupting) The Countess Veronique Fabian LeFleur.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: (slightly embarrassed) Giselle, they do not care about these things in America. (to Hooker) This is my maid servant, Giselle Duvillard. We are sorry that you lost your watch.

dialogues.speaker: . _HOOKER
dialogues.text: Oh, it wasn't mine, Miss LeFleur.

dialogues.speaker: GISELLE
dialogues.text: Countess LeFleur.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: Giselle!

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: A Mr. Jerome Hawthorne lost it in here tonight, and is quite anxious to get it back. It's an Elgin Special with a monogrammed J.H. on e back. He's offering a thousand dollar reward for its return.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: (honestl. relieved Oh, then it's not an expensive one. Hooker struggles to maintain his nonchalance in the face such a remar It's a hard one for a poor boy to swallow. He looks for some indication that she may be kidding. He doesn't get one.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Well, it was just that it was very personal to Mr. Hawthorne. It was given to him by his father just be- ore he was killed in the Battle of Belaue Wood.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: (truly moved) Oh, how sad, If we find it, we will bring it to ou, how do you ' say...on the doub

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both women permit themselves a little laugh at their mast of this English idiom.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: (taking his leave Thank you, Miss LeFleur.

dialogues.speaker: GISELLE
dialogues.text: (sullenly) Countess LeFleur.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOOKER 15
dialogues.text: We follow him as he returns to Eirie, out of sight of the two women.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You were right, Eirie. Money's nothin' to her. She's a countess.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 15
dialogues.text: HOOKER (Cont'd) French. Not a bad egg for a coun- tess. Maybe in France they're not so snot-nosed. It's obvious that Veronique's charm has rekindled some second thoughts in Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Aw c'mon. Underneath they're all alike. You're not softening up on me, are ya Hooker?

dialogues.speaker: ON EIRIE 16
dialogues.text: This time we follow Eirie as he makes his way to the tabl He boldly props himself down right next to Veronique in t booth, talking to her in a conspiritorial fashion, out of the side of his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Look lady, I know you don't know me, but I need a little help. The manager here's got it in for me, and I'd appreciate it if you could pretend like we was friends and everything. Like we been sittin’ here for a long time, havin' a - nice evening....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Hooker suddenly appears at the table. Eirie pretends t be carrying on a conversation with the woman, who doesn't know what to make of him.

dialogues.speaker: __, HOOKER
dialogues.text: . {to Eirie) Fisher, I thought I told you to stay outta here.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: It's a free country, Stewart. A man can dance if he wants to. (to the Countess) . Me and my date was just about to cut up the rug a little, wasn't we honey? The Countess doesn't know what to say. She has no idea what Eirie is talking about.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Stand up and empty out your pockets.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 17
dialogues.text: Eirie hesitates a second, then stands up and reluctantly empties out his pockets. He shows nothing but a wallet and a pair of keys.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: See, I'm clean.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Good, then you won't have anything to weigh you down on the way out. Or do I have to call the police?

dialogues.speaker: _., EIRIE
dialogues.text: (deciding it's _ time to leave) All right, all right. I didn't want to hang out in this dive anyway. Eirie beats a speedy retreat.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: Who was that man?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER -
dialogues.text: Oh, he's a cheap crook. A pickpocket, a fence, you name it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both women are visibly frightened to have been in the pre sence of such a man. Veronique glances down at where Eiri was sitting and something catches her eye -- there's a go watch on the seat. She picks it up quickly and hands it t Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: Mr. Stewart, there's a watch here. I think it's your friend's.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: (inspecting the watch) . It's Hawthorne's all right. Fisher probably stole it from him and took it out of his pocket when I asked to search him. The women are really scared now.

dialogues.speaker: GISELLE
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to call the police?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Wouldn't do any good unless we had found the watch on him. Whatever, you found the watch. You have a reward coming.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: Oh, but I could not take it. I have done nothing to deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: , HOOKER ,
dialogues.text: I insist. Mr. Hawthorne will be very unhappy with me if I don't follow his instructions. You found the watch. The money is yours. Please, he will be most insulted if you turn it down.

dialogues.speaker: . VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: _ (resigned) . All right, I do not wish to offend the man. . _ (to Giselle) When in America, I suppose we must do as the Americans.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER , 19
dialogues.text: hands her the envelope with the boodle in it. She puts it in her purse without even bothering to check it.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, but if I may be so bold, I wouldn't carry that money in your purse. Not in a neighborhood like this. You walk down the street with a purse in plain view, you're gonna lose it. ere are twenty other thieves outside just like Fisher, only worse. The two women are immediately concerned.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE
dialogues.text: What should we do? HOOKER . Here, let me show you something. If I were you, I'd put all my money in the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: VERONIQUE 20
dialogues.text: complies, immediately, pulling out a bankroll that knocks

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 20
dialogues.text: Hooker's eyes out. She puts it into the envelope and then passes it to Giselle, who dips into her purse and adds he money to it. She turns her body as she does so, so that Hooker cannot see how much money she has. Hooker is amuse by her modesty. Giselle then licks the envelope and seals it.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: May I have the envelope a second? Giselle hesitates, but Veronique makes her hand it over.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: All right, you take the envelope and stick it up under your arm, inside your coat, like this. Hooker demonstrates by slipping the envelope inside his tuxedo coat and up into his armpit. By shooting from the side, we see that there is already another envelope there the one with the cut paper.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: That way you can feel it all the time, and no pickpickets will be looking for it there. He reaches back inside his coat and pulls out the envelop but of course it's not the one he put in. It's the one wi the cut paper. He hands it to Veronique, who thanks him a hands it to Giselle, who tucks it up inside her coat, gla ing both ways to make sure no one saw her do it. HOOKER . I am sorry for all the commotion here tonight. I hope you enjoyed your evening, Countess. Giselle allows herself a little smile that Hooker is fina using the proper term of address. The Countess nods that evening has been satisfactory, and Hooker takes his leave

dialogues.speaker: ON HOOKER
dialogues.text: We follow him as he walks right on out of the ballroom an joins Eirie on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is not nearly as elated as we might expect.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Everything go okay? : 39 ¥ CONTINUED  22 23 24

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was easy. I don't even think we needed the build up. I coulda asked 'em for the money out- right and they'da given it to me. Not that I'm proud of it.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: (hefting the envelope) Yeah, well let me see what we got here. Feels like enough to open our own steel mill. Eirie rips open the envelope and pulls out the most beaut ful stack of construction paper we've ever seen. Not a dollar bill in sight. Both Hooker and Eirie stare at it i shock for a secon Then it begins to dawn on then.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Hooker, we been had. Barely are the words out of Eirie’s mouth than Hooker rac back into the cl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker zeroes in on table sixteen. It's empty. He races back outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker frantically looks up and down the street for some sign of the two women. HOOKER ; I find that broad, I'm gonna wring her neck. Forget it. She’ 5 TRrobably halfway home with our thirty bucks by now. Wouldn't that rot your socks. Eirie is somewhat amused by the whole thing. Hooker is fit to be tied. He literally begins jumping up and down.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: We gotta do somethin'. We'll call the police, that's what we'll do. Christ, what kinda town are they runnin' where people can 90, around pullin' this sorta thing. This burg is crawlin' with grifters and the cops are pickin’ nose.  25 26 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie can't believe this outpouring of righteousness from Hooker. Hooker continues his tirade as they get into thei limousine.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Usin' construction paper yet. Think how the people who made that paper would feel if they knew what she was using it for. They thought. the’ were makin’ somethin' nice for little kids. This is the kinda thing that gives construction paper a bad name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the limousine pulls out, we move to reveal that Lonneg man, Floyd, has been watching the departure from a car ac the street. We can't see who's in the back seat, but we c guess. cut To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls up in front of the building and Hooke and Eirie get out. hey are just about to go up the front steps when two thugs jump out of the shadows, scaring the hell out of all of us, not to mention Hooker and Eirie. Hooker tries to run for it, but he's caught and slammed u against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: You Johnny Hooker?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: THUG
dialogues.text: We're from Atlas Tuxedo. You told our guy to bill you. We checked your credit -- you ain't got none. Our boss don't like to be stiffed. That tux'll be ten bucks.

dialogues.speaker: . __ HOOKER
dialogues.text: I ain't got it.

dialogues.speaker: . THUG
dialogues.text: Then you either give up the tux or your good looks. Hooker pulls out his pockets with his best "have mercy" smile. He looks from some sign that it's winning the thugs over. Fat chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. HOOKER'S APARTMENT BUILDING’~ STAIRWAY - NIGHT 28 walking up the stairs of Hooker's apartment building. Hooker, having lost the tuxedo, is now clad only in his YMCA m shorts, his knee socks (suspenders) and, of course his alligator shoes. It hasn't been his night.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Ya know with things a little tough and all, maybe we oughta go see Gondorff. s letter said he's got a big house down there in Florida with a yard and everything. We could lie around in the sun a little, maybe borrow a few bucks.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I'm not goin' down there with my hat in my hand. He thinks I don't know how to take care of myself.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: He's not gonna be like that. He's in the chips. He'd be glad to help ya out.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: (tired as hell) . I don't know. We'll talk about it in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eirie starts off toward his room as Hooker tries to open the door to his own room. Suddenly the door opens by itself and Hooker finds himself looking at a large Man in a food-stained undershirt.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Somethin' I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeh, this is my apartment.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Used to be. They moved you out an hour ago. Seems you wasn't paid up.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: I'll be damned. They got somebody to live here.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You know what they did with my clothes?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: They pawned 'em to get the rent you owed.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: Ha, you got the last iaugh on ‘em there, Hooker. They won't get two months' worth outa those duds. Hooker gives Eirie a look that could melt a brick.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well I'd love to talk to you guys all right, but I gotta go decorate the den. Without further ado, he closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE HALLWAY 30
dialogues.text: Hooker and Eirie start back down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: ’ You ready to go see Gondorff now?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, what the hell. You got some clothes you could lend me? EIRIE . Sure, but we don't have nothin' for train tickets.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I know. Just get me a badge and I'll do the rest. No more strike- outs tonight, Eirie. Look out. Johnny Hooker is back. cut TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Hooker and Eirie as they come into the station and fan out in different directions. Hooker is wearing Eirie's clothes, which look ridiculous on him, The pants are a good eight inches too short, and the shirt is burst ing at the seams, showing patches of skin between the: uttons.  32 33 34

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Birie into the gift shop where he goes to the t section. He looks enrough several small novelties until h finds what he's looking for -- a little tinh replica of a policeman's badge. He looks around for store detectives, and seeing none, slips the badge into his pocket. cut To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in another part of the station. We see him removing a sig from a door, but the angle prohibits us from being able t read it. He drops the sign in a waste can and walks out into the passenger lobby. Eirie passes him and slips him the tin badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After scanning the area carefully for a minute, Hooker go up to a conservative-looking Businessman, who's busy read e schedule board. Hooker flashes open his wallet to revea the little tin badge and then quickly closes it again.

dialogues.speaker: _ BOOKER
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. Treasury Department. I'd like to ask you a few questions. BUSINESSMAN . What for? I haven't done anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station. Have you made any purchases here today?

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: (reluctantly) | well, yes, a small gift, and some ‘ood. _, HOOKER . Then I'm afraid we'll have to im- ound your money until we're sure at it's all good. Can I see your wallet please.

dialogues.speaker: __ BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: (handing it over) But I got a train to make.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: It'll only take twenty minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down hall.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: But what about all these other people?

dialogues.speaker: __. HOOKER
dialogues.text: (blowing up) We'll get ‘em! Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here ya know. We go around advertisin ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh? (pointing to his shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘You think I'm wearin' this rag here ‘cause I like it? Christ, everybody thi life's a holiday or somethin when you got a badge. {pouring it on I been here bor thirteen hours, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people. . You try to help 'em and they spit ‘on ya. I shoulda let. you gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes. The Businessman is totally shamed.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, really I am, but I can't wait twenty minutes. My train leaves in ten.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER \
dialogues.text: All right, I'll give ya a break. (pointing to a hall Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left. Go in that door and wait at the cashier window. I'll take this... (indicates _ _the money) . +;-in the back and run it through right away. We'll have ya outa there in a couple minutes.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. You don't know how much I appreciate this.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: with a ittle wave) Think nothing of it. The Businessman goes off down the hall, more than gratefu for the special treatment.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TICKET COUNTER 35
dialogues.text: Hooker, meanwhile, joins Eirie and the two spring over to buy tickets for Florida.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE BUSINESSMAN 36
dialogues.text: as we follow him down the hall to the unmarked door. He strides on through to find himself face-to-face with a wa of busily flushing urinals. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: sprinting out of the train station, having seen Hooker an Eirie buying their tickets. He races up to the limousine in which Lonnegan is waiting. (out of breath) | Hey, they're takin’ a powder on the train. We better hurry if we're gonna put’ the snatch on 'em.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Let 'em go.

dialogues.speaker: _.. . FLOYD
dialogues.text: (in disbelief) . Let 'em go? Christ, what if they skip the country or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: , LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: They're goin' down to Florida to see Gondorff. They'll be back. All of ‘em. Floyd just looks at Lonnegan in wonderment. How does he know this kinda stuff. . cur TO  38 39 40

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick wp Hooker and Eirie getting off the train, and winding their way through the crowd. Both are travelin light.” Hooker, of course, has no luggage at all -- jus the clothes Eirie lent him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I gotta get some decent clothes. I can't show up at Gondorff's lookin' like this.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: You got the money right on your feet there. We shoulda thought of it earlier.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (looking down at his beloved alligators) Aw, no.... cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker has his alligator shoes up on the counter. The Pawnbroker looks them over with the crushing indifference that characterizes his breed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're alligator, ya know.

dialogues.speaker: PAWNBROKER
dialogues.text: So what. We got five thousand of ‘em in the Everglades across the street.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: (pissed) Not Brazilian ones. The Pawnbroker hands over a twenty dollar bill. Hooker doesn't like it, but he takes it. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Eirie are walking along with a copy of Gondorf letter in hand, obviously looking for an address. Hooker has on his new clothes now, and while they're none too st ish, at least they fit. They find the address they want on the curb and look up expecting to see Gondorff's house Instead they are greeted with a sign that says: FLORIDA STATE PENITENTIARY, Eirie stands there with his mouth ope Hooker is just plain disgusted.  41 42 43

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: A big house with a yard, huh? cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Eirie sit in the visiting room awaiting the appearance of Gondorff. Hooker is barely able to control his anger. Eirie, of course, is fascinated with prison and everything in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A.door opens and out comes Gondorff, wearing a smile as wide as the stripes, which clothe him from head to toe. He's also wearing the fedora hat which is his trademark. GONDORFF . Howdy. Glad you could make it.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Bite off.

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What the hell are you s0 sore about. I'm the one that's in jail. You remember that senator I took on a stocks deal? I got a job as a gardener in a cemetery, figurin' nobody there is gonna put finger on me. Turns out the sena- tor comes down to observe Veterans Day and I'm out there waterin' the lawn. First honest work I ever did and look what happens to me. I been here two years.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You coulda told us. +.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Then I never woulda got ya down here, I knew if you thought I was in the money, you'd come down and try to mooch some.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (incensed) I don't need your goddamn money. I jot a zinc mine in Cuba, some oil interests in Japan and a race horse that's definitely Kentucky Derby material. Not to mention the next light-heavyweight champion.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Typhoon Taylor.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Who sold him to ya, Jackie Pope?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, you know Jackie?

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Christ, he tried to sell me the guy four years ago, only he was as cal in' him Tugboat Taylor then. Every time he loses, Jackie gives him a ue name. He's better now." vt got him fightin' a contender next week at the Jersey Gardens. I tell ya, Typhoon's got a right hand like a steam drill.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: How do you know? He's never hit anything with it.

dialogues.speaker: ., HOOKER
dialogues.text: I been workin' with him personally. I used to be a Golden Gloves cham- pion, ya know.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: You're a great businessman, Hooker. Did this horse you bought have all three legs?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Some day you're gonna be sorry you don't have a piece of my action.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Look, I don't even care if ou showed up just to mooch. had some dough here, I'd ive Tit to a. Unfortunately, all I got me is | bad news. (pause) somebody’ id lied Kid Twist. Hooker and Eirie are stunned.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: But I just saw him a couple days ago. Police in Atlantic Ci Caty +f a tip. They pulled him out o e bay with cement on his feet.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Lonnegan?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I thought so at first, but this isn't his style. Besides, what would he be doin' in Atlantic City. word is it was a hood named ' Carlo Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: KER
dialogues.text: It's not like Twist _to con a racketeer. How could he get so down on his luck to do somethin' like that?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Look at us three. We paintin' any pictures of success? It's a question that needs no reply. The answer is obviou

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: You gonna go after this guy?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: After the Lonnegan con, I said we'd never do anything like that again. We keep stinging heavy gees, no matter how good the reason, and pretty soon there won't be any place safe for us.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I figure we ought to stick to that line of thinking...next time. A smile creeps onto Gondorff's face. He was hoping Hooker would feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: __. GONDORFF
dialogues.text: They're lettin' me outa here on Wednesday. Billie's comin' down with some tickets for Atlantic City. We'll be back in time to catch your boy's fight. See ya en. Hooker and Eirie nod good-bye, and are shown out of the visiting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow Gondorff as he's led back to his cell by a guar named Clancy. It's obvious the two know each other well. Hey Clancy, they don't ha ey Clancy ey don ve any zinc in Cuba, aS they? : ‘ CLANCY | Nope, ain't got no oi] in Japan, either. They're still runnin’ the Kentucky Derby though. As Gondorff disappears down the hall, we: cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: beginning on the day of Gondorff's release. We pick up Gondorff coming out of the prison gates, wearing a prison issue suit and carrying a small satchel of belongings. He dances a little jig as Billie rushes forward to greet him They embrace with an enthusiasm worthy of the occasion, a Hooker and Eirie look on somewhat sheepishly. A cab waits behind them. cut TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes directly into one of the self-photo booths and dr the blinds. We don't know why he's doing this yet, but th purposefulness with which he goes about it indicates some ing beyond vanity. cur TO  47 48 49 50 51

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up a heavyset, middle-aged man, known in con circ as the Big Ohio, picking cases of bourbon off the conveyo line and loading them onto a forklift pallet. A shift for man happens by and hands him an envelope, hunching his shoulders to indicate he has no idea what's in it. The Bi Ohio stops to open it and pulls out a photo booth picture of Gondorff with his hand to his nose in the traditional confidence man's salute (the "office"). Below the picture is nothing but the words: JERSEY GARDEN. 8:30 PM. THE FOURTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Ohio smiles knowingly to himself. Suddenly we hea the splintering of bottles as the rapidly piling up cases begin to be crushed at the end of the conveyor, spilling bourbon all over the floor. The Big Ohio could care less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: J,J. Singleton is in the grandstand watching a race throu binoculars when a steward hands him an envelope. He opens it to find the same picture that the Big Ohio got. He ponders the message a second and then begins to gather up is things, completely oblivious to the People around him who are going crazy rooting home their favorites.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a handsome, debonair man partaking of his midday m while his butler is busy unpacking his suitcase. The man the Tuxedo Kid, so named because he always wears a tux un he's sleeping or on a con. He has them in twelve differen colors. On his lunch tray is an envelope. He opens it to find a picture of guess who. Tuxedo motions to the butler start putting the clothes back in the suitcase. As the bu struggles to keep a stiff upper lip, we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the night of Typhoon Taylor's fight. We pick up Hook Gondorff, Eirie and Billie as they pull up in front of th Jersey Garden. As we might have guessed, it's in Jersey, but it ain't no garden. Gondorff looks the place over, hoping they can get the fight in before the place falls d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gondorff and company move through the arena on the wa to their seats, we notice that the Big Ohio, J.J. Singlet and the Tuxedo Kid are hanging out at different points al the way.

dialogues.speaker: ON SINGLETON
dialogues.text: getting a drink at the refreshment stand.

dialogues.speaker: ON TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: getting a shoeshine.

dialogues.speaker: ON BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: in his seat reading, the program. All three acknowledge Gondorff and the others with a subtle "office" but make no overt signs of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING
dialogues.text: The two wrestlers are grape. ing away in a pile of mud, part of the Garden's lates promotional gimmick.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Aw, don't pay no attention to that, Lawry, the promoter here, thinks he's gotta do stuff like that to build the gate. Last week he had Genghis the Greek wrasslin' the Morgue Man in a ring full of dead fis

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: (wishing he'd seen it No kiddin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff, Hooker and Eirie arrive at Typhoon Taylor's dressing room. We can tell because Tay. or's name is. chalked on a blackboard which hangs on the door. There are four other names on it too. 52 53 54

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker pokes his head inside. Taylor is sitting in a card game with a couple other fighters. It's hard for him to hold his cards because his hands are taped.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How ya feelin’, Typhoon.

dialogues.speaker: TYPHOON
dialogues.text: (trying to figure out what to discard) - Don't worry, boss, I'm gonna murder 'en. Hooker looks to the trainer, Shorty, who's reading a pulp devoted to fight stories.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Shouldn't he be gettin' his gloves on?

dialogues.speaker: SHORTY
dialogues.text: Naw, the Golden Dread ain't due to lose for another ten minutes or so.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, all right.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: THE ARENA AGAIN - NIGHT — 58 It's later now. Hooker and friends are ali in their seats The ring is in the final stages of being cleaned up as th fighters enter the ring. mud has all been shoveled into wheelbarrows and the canvas s has been mopped up. The rin Announcer steps to the mike.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING
dialogues.text: The Announcer is at the mike.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to the Garden's semi-main event. Seven rounds of boxing. In the red corner, weighing one eighty-two and wearing the ‘black trunks, the number six ranking light-heavyweight contender, phe pride of Dublin, Irish Billy lealy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Healy dances out to even more scattered applause.

dialogues.speaker: . ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And in the blue corner, weighing one ninety-two, wearing the white trunks, big wind that blows nobody good, Eddie 'Typhoon' Taylor. Typhoon dances out to even more scattered applause. Hooke and Eirie have been visibly moved by the Announcer's intr duction of Taylor. What poetry.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You watch my guy, Henry. He's got the greatest right I've ever seen.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 60
dialogues.text: The bell rings and the fighters come out. Immediately, Typhoon backs Healy into a corner and unleashes the famou right. It misses, crashing mightily into a ring ost. It danm near splinters the thing. Hooker wasn't kidding. Taylor has a great right. Unfortunately, we're about to find out what he doesn't have -- any defense. While Typhoon is busy admiring the damage he's done to the post Healy blasts two shots to the body and a left hook to the chin. Typhoon goes on his face.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOOKER 61
dialogues.text: Hooker jumps up immediately and hops down to ringside to talk to Taylor, whose head is hanging over the side of th ring.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Don't let this upset ya, Typhoon. It was just a lucky shot. He's gonna be comin’ in on ya now. Go into a crouch like you're hurt, and when he wades in, uncork the right. You got at? :

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING . 62
dialogues.text: Typhoon nods in such a way that lets us know he'd be luck if he knew his own name Tight now. He gets up at eight an waits for Healy to come in on him. He crouches, but none too sure of his directions at this point, uncorks a left

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 62
dialogues.text: instead of a right. It catches Healy full on the chin. Unfortunately Healy doesn't seem to notice. Whatever power there was in Typhoon's left is gone. Healy unloads a right cross to Typhoon's jaw, Typhoon, being a much more observant type, goes on his back, landing very close to where he went down last time.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Get it UB Typhoon. This don't look good.

dialogues.speaker: TYPHOON
dialogues.text: (woozy) Leave me alone. A guy can only take so much. I gave it my all.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Your all! It's only thirty seconds into the goddamn first round.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no use. hoon is taking the rest of the night off. Hooker stands there stunned as Taylor is counted out. Gondorff comes down to commiserate.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: If only he coulda thrown one more right.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: It's a hard punch to throw when you're lying down. As Gondorff and Hooker walk away from the ring, the camer moves to reveal another presence in the arena.

dialogues.speaker: ON LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: High up in the stands we find Doyle Lonnegan taking in th whole scene. Floyd as always is next to .

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I told you they'd be back.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Look at that punk Hooker. If I was that ugly I'd shoot myself.  66

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan says nothing, but he's obviously amused at the ability of Floyd's emotions to alter his eyesight. Gondor and company are almost out of the arena now.

dialogues.speaker: __. FLOYD
dialogues.text: They're leavin'. We go get ‘em now?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I told you no, Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: What the hell are we waiting for? After what those guys did to us. I tell ya, that bastard Hooker is mine. I got a bullet with his name on it. Actin' like he was some kinda hot poop, tellin' us he could fix races, callin' Slade and me Mutt and Jeff. I don't let nobody get away with that shit.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: He's not gonna get away with any- thing. He and Gondorff are gonna pay me back and then you'll have your day.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: (shaking his head in disbelief) I don't get it. LONNEGAN . If everybody could understand it, it wouldn't be much of a plan, now, would it?

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: I still think we're makin' a mistake screwin' around like this.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be enough to kill them now. They'd leave this world thinking Doyle Lonnegan was a ~ stupid man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Hooker enter the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker nods to the Chinese store owner and makes his way the back of the store. He opens a large meat refrigerator door and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instead of hanging beef sides in the refrigerator, we fin a small meeting room. Around the table in the center are Gondorff, Eirie, Singleton, the Big Ohio and the Tuxedo K Gondorff is dressed in his usual casual attire -- sleeve~ less T-shirt, fedora hat and cigar. The Tuxedo Kid provid a splash of color with a lime-green number. Hooker pulls a chair.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: All right, let's get started. What's the news on this guy, J.J.? Singleton organizes some notes he's made.

dialogues.speaker: SINGLETON
dialogues.text: I tell ya, Henry, Macalinski's been around. He started as a strong-arm at a carnival. Then he ran a shell game, a monte booth, even did some of the magic when the magician was too soused to go on. But most of all, he discouraged the customers from takin’ too close a look at how they were losin' their money. They say he still likes to do a trick or two at his parties when he gets a few drinks in him. A guy walked out once when he was doin' a rope trick. They found him the next day with his feet in a drill press. He never walked at all after that, let alone out of a party. This piece of information has a very sobering effect on t group. EIRIE . Why do we always gotta go up against these types?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: If they weren't these types, we wouldn't have to.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: So if he's not a carney worker anymore, what the hell is he? BIG OHIO . He became an enforcer for Gandi Bellino in '34. At the time, Bellino was tryin' to nail down all the prostitution in the city. He put Macalinski in charge of his gunsels. After Macalinski _ finished torpedoing the opposition, he torpedoed Bellino. Now he runs more gris than anybody on the | island. He's still a shitty magi- cian, though. INDORF’ He musta made a few enemies during all this.

dialogues.speaker: _ BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: Yeah, but nothin' he can't handle. He's got some sore spots, though. For one thing, he can't stand Negroes. Guys like JoJo Berry and Willie Bates. He says they give prostitution a bad name by sellin’ cheap. It really frosts his butt when they pick up the good white talent. Gondorff says nothing, but we can tell this bit of infor- mation is not lost on him.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Okay. Tuxedo, what do you got on his personal habits? oo, TUXEDO KID Macalinski's the glamour type. Snappy dresser, big tipper, owns the Bluebird Club down on the pier. Buys a new suit every day, wears it once and then burns it. They say he's fot fity-four diamond rings and ee hundred pair of shoes.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I guess he doesn't believe in burn- ing those.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID.
dialogues.text: He's got every vice there is and a few I'm not acquainted with, but his biggest weakness is the janes. He thinks he's death to women.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Is he?

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: You never see him with less than four. This creates a general feeling of disgust around the tabl If there's one thing a grifter can't stand in a mark, it' pretention.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Do any of these dames ever stay tight with him?

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Naw, he doesn't like women that much. He just can't stand it when they don't like hin.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: _ Looks like we might be able to use a woman on him in the setup.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: If we can find one with grifting experience.

dialogues.text: He'd be a perfect mark except for the fact t he probably knows all the standard cons from his carney days.

dialogues.text: Then we'll have to go with a new one. Watchin’ hoon the other night, I got an idea for a fight con that might be good for this clown. I thought we'd call it the Gondorff after its founder -- I mean until we come up with some~ thing better. Immediately everyone at the table comes up with something better. Gondorff has to call for order.

dialogues.speaker: _. GONDORFF
dialogues.text: The Gondorff it is. I haven't got it all figured yet, but we'll need a gym to start with. J.J. and the Big Ohio can get on that. Tuxedo can handle the bookmaking, The only other thing we need is... , (pause) .»a fighter. Everyone looks to Hooker. Hooker would rather they looked at somebody else.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: It couldn't be any worse than when Lonnegan's guys were shootin’ at ya. Hooker realizes it's useless to protest. He nods his head in acceptance of his role.

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: All right then, we'll all have to work on percentage. We're pretty short of cash. That queer the deal for anybody? Gondorff looks around the table. Everybody's in.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Okay, let's go to work.

dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: (flashing his toy badge) Eddie Hoover, FBI. Your saleslady here, Miss Newberry, is wanted for extortion and embezzlement in fifteen states.

dialogues.text: Don't believe this guy, Mr. Hertel. _ MANAGER . But her name is Sherman. Veronica Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER

dialogues.speaker: HOOKE
dialogues.text: That's why she’s so eeod. We been chasin' her for a year and a half, but I guess your luck finally ran out, huh sis

Veronica stops in midsentence, realizing what she's just admitted. Mr. Hertel is more upset by this than if she we an embezzler. Whatever doubts he had about Hooker are now one. He gives Veronica his most scandalized glare. She ows she's had it. __ VERONICA . Aw, the hell with it. I was tired ‘a workin' in your crappy store any- way. cONT INUED  75 76 77

dialogues.text: We pick them up as they emerge onto the street.

dialogues.text: Just wanted you to know I'm not a sore loser.

Christ, I gotta give Harriet twenty five percent, I gotta buy the clothes, pay off the maitre d', buy a few drinks and I hook into some jerk who's only good for thirty bucks. if you were any kind of pro at all you would've sweetened that boodie with ~ a 100 on the top, instead of a crummy twenty.

In addition, dressing | rooms are being built at both ends. Gondorff, at present, using one of them as an office. Hooker strolls through th gym, taking in the work, and then enters the office.

dialogues.text: The most exclusive club in Atlantic City and definitely i the tradition of the great supper clubs of the early fort Characterized by its bold deco design, satin curtains and tablecloths and an elevated bandstand with its Busby Berk backdrops, the Bluebird prides itself on its elegance. Th bandstand is actually divided into three tiers, the top t (containing the drummer and piano player) a flood twelve above the floor, The waiters are all dressed in black tux edos, the band in tails, and the cocktail waitresses and cigarette girls in tuxedoettes -- backless tuxedo jackets tuxedo shorts with cummerbund, high heels with spats, and top hat -- much like the girls in Fatha Hines Grand Terra orus.

Both men look at each other with contempt, but each adopt civil tone.

dialogues.text: Madam? aE

dialogues.text: (to Veronica I'm Carlo Macalinski. I own the club here. You may have heard of me. VERONICA . Noe I'm sorry. I'm new in Atlantic ‘ity. (offerin ‘her hand Lola Forrest. Veronica turns to Gondorff now, He takes her hand and kis it as he introduces himself. Macalinski is disgusted by Gondorff's elaborate chivalry.

dialogues.text: (to Veronica) I was wondering if oud like to go somewhere nice for dinner. I know a place across the....

dialogues.text: (gettin hot now) Who you talkin' to about class, brown boy. I've had over five hundred fe- males in my life.

Eirie apologizes profusely, but receives nothing but verb abuse in return. While Macalinski is busy toweling off his suit, Gondorff comes over and attempts to dry Macalinski's hair with a n kin. He makes one swipe, and’ suddenly Macalinski is bald

We'll just send this rug out to be dry cleaned and you won't have to wash your hair. What'll they think of next? Is that your real nose? Macalinski's humiliation has given way to pure rage. dialogues.text: Macalinski has said this with his back to Veronica so tha she hasn't heard it.- Gondorff figures maybe it's time to off for a while. Both men take their seats, as Macalinski reaches for a deck of cards in the center of the table.

dialogues.text: (surprising]: __ composed now) I think we owe it to Miss Forrest to settle our differences like gentlemen. A simple game of skill. Macalinski puts two cards face down on the table. He then goes through the deck and pulls out the queen of diamonds He holds it up for Gondorff and Veronica to see.

As he does it see him slip one card up his sleeve. th . . MACALINERI I e game is s @ enough. I move the cards around. Mr. Berrigan tries to pick out the queen. If he does, he'll have the pleasure of Miss Forrest's Company alone. If not, he'll leave & club and never return. Fair enough, Berrigan.

As Macalinski takes the queen back from Veronica, he palm it and replaces it with the card up his sleeve, It's done in a movement so deft that we can only see it in slow mot Gondorff and Veronica can't possibly have seen it at all. Macalinski puts the new card face down in the middle agai with everyone assuming it's still the queen.

dialogues.speaker: . _MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: _All right, Berrigan, your turn. Macalinski begins moving the cards again, more quickly th time, but it's still not difficult to follow the card tha should have been the queen. It ends up in the middle agai

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Well, which one is it? Gondorff studies the cards. It seems like there's no way can win. None of them are queens. Gondorff puts his hands on the two outside cards.

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I'll say it's neither of these two. Before Macalinski can protest, Gondorff flips over the tw cards. Neither, of course, is the queen.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Looks like I win. The queen has got to be the other one. Macalinski does a slow burn, but there's nothing he can d He's been outfoxed. He goes to take in the non-queen that still face down, but Gondorff's hand is on it first. -

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I just wanta thank the little lady before she goes back in the deck. Gondorff flips over the card. It's a four of clubs. Veron reacts with feigned shock. Macalinski tries to maintain h ignity.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Tf you'll excuse us, Miss Forrest and I have a date for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (to Veronica) . You're not really gonna go out with him, are ya?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: It would be a pleasure. As Veroncia and Gondorff get up to leave, Gondorff flips dollar bill toward Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: That's for the use of the table. Keep the change. (pointing to Macalinski's Ss Maybe you can get yourself a shine. Macalinski gives Gondorff a look that could kill.

dialogues.speaker: WITH GONDORFF 94
dialogues.text: as he turns and leaves the club with Veronica on his am. He winks at Hooker as he passes his table.

dialogues.speaker: ON MACALINSKI 95
dialogues.text: as he starts back toward his own table. There's a on his shoulder. He turns around to find a very agitate: Lionel Richardson.

dialogues.speaker: _. RICHARDSON
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, I was told you were the owner. Can you tell me where the green phone 1s?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: He walks away, leaving poor Richardson to make another fu search for his telephone call. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macalinski, accompanied by three bodyguards, comes out a door of the club and walks down the pier to the amusement center. He's generally in a foul mood, and has sent the women home for the night. :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A couple of concessionaires say hello to Macalinski, but doesn't respond. As he reaches the park entrance, Hooker approaches from the side. He's dressed more working class now, complete with a Cagney beret. He adopts the speech pattern of a prizefighter.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Mr. Macalinski. Hooker gets no acknowledgement from Macalinski, but is im diately surrounded by two bodyguards. Macalinski walks on ahead.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I wanta see Macalinski. “BODYGUARD He don't wanna see nobody.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Tell him it's about Ivory Berrigan. One of the bodyguards hustles ahead to Macalinski. They h a short conference and the Bodyguard waves Hooker and the second bodyguard forward. Macalinski, however, doesn't wa for them. He continues on toward his objective.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Where are we goin'? Can't I talk to him here?

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: He's takin' his ride. He does it every night before he goes to bed. Says it helps him sleep.  98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally Macalinski reaches his destination -- the famous Parachute Jump, an awesome tower of steel reaching 300 fe into the air, culminating at the top in a brightly lit ei pronged platform. Suspended by long cables from each pron of the platform are the flimsy-looking two-seater chairs, which now dangle a few feet off the ground waiting for th next round of riders. Having no weight in them at this point, the chairs swing slightly in the breeze, sending Pinging noises up the cables which just seem to disappear in the dark sky above. Not a ride for the faint of heart. The Operator of the parachute is quite familiar with Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: . OPERATOR
dialogues.text: Evening, Mr. Macalinski. Oughta be _ able to see all the way to Philadelphia tonight. Macalinski just nods. For the first time, he turns to fac Hooker, who has caught up by now. . MACALINSKT . You was in the club tonight, right?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but....

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: {pointing to the _ Parachute chair) Get in. Hooker looks up at the tower. He's not at all sure he wan to get in that seat.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: You wanna talk or don't ya? Hooker nods weakly and gets into the seat. The Operator s them in and the chair begins to rise.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: The name's Florian, Bobby Florian. Hooker offers his hand. Macalinski ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: ,MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: What about Berrigan? HOOKER ; That thing he did with your hair and all. That wasn't no accident. :

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: o~

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 98-A
dialogues.text: HOOKER (Cont'd) He'd been plannin' to do that as a favor for some friends of his, JoJo Berry and Will Bates, who don't like you so good, just to make you look bad in your own joint.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) . And you felt so bad about it, you decided to tell me so I could kill ya.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hey, look, I got nothin' against you. I'm a fighter, not a mob gee. I just done what he tells me up to now.

dialogues.speaker: __MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Are these business interests he says he's got all fighters?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, me and a couple other guys who ain't worth shinola. He makes his dough offa my right hand. Hooker holds up a clenched right fist to demonstrate the point.

dialogues.speaker: ___ HOOKER
dialogues.text: See, when I signed with this guy, he told me he was gonna bring me along right.... At this point, Hooker happens to glance down at the groun

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: which is now about 150 feet away. It scares the hell out im.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH HOOKER
dialogues.text: op FOOKER . Anyway, I win my first four fights in a row all by knockouts, three of ‘em in the first heat. So he gets me a fight with Alvarado, who's ranked number fifteen. The guy's so far

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 99-A
dialogues.text: : HOOKER (Cont'd) over the hill, you can't see him no more, and Berrigan tells me I gotta throw the fight so he can pay off some markers. Take a dive in the fifth. So I'm out there, fresh as a daisy, ain't been hit with nothin' all night, and I gotta lie down. Hooker steals another quick glance at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: The height is starting to get to him.

dialogues.speaker: BACK WITH HOOKER AND MACALINSKI 100-A
dialogues.text: Macalinski, meanwhile, continues to take in the sights li he was looking out a train window.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: So he leaves me alone the next three fights, I bust three more guys, including Frankie Carl, who ain't no bum. I take him out in the fourth. .So now I got a shot at Kelley ina week, who couldn't beat me with an axe, and Berrigan wants me to go in the water again. Every time I start gettin' someplace, he tanks me out. T ain't gonna take that no more. I coulda been eight and zero by now and fightin' high rankers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The height is about 240 feet now and the wind is beginnin to blow the chair around a little. Hooker is struggling t maintain his cool.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: That's very touching, but what do ya need me for?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: If I cross Berrigan, I'm gonna need some protection. I don't take that dive, and his people '1l break my legs. They tell me you got some muscle in this town. I don't know if it's enough to handle Berrigan, but I'm willin' to take a chance.

dialogues.speaker: _ MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (chuckling to himself) Don't think I got enough to handle Berrigan, huh?

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: I'm tellin' ya, he's no good. I seen what he's done to some people. Nobody wants to mess with him. _ _MACALINSKI ; Well, assuming I don't die of fright, what's in it for me?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Well, I got some money goin' down on this fight. I'm layin' six grand on me. I cut you in for, say, twenty percent at even odds, that's, ah....

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (instantly) Twelve hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: That oughta be worth some protection.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: About fifteen minutes. . HOOKER . Okay...Fifty percent. Look, I ain't got any more. What do you say?

dialogues.speaker: ON MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Macalinski ‘isn't about to say. top now.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hooker takes a look, but *two feet He looks out over the panorama.

dialogues.speaker: _ _, MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (pointing __ horthwest) Arnie was right. You can see Philadelphia. u ickly fixes again on a in front of his face. He really looks ba 101 102 The chair has reached the 103 oint about now. The rigid expression of one who is really scared stiff.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 103
dialogues.text: Suddenly the bottom drops out and the chair plunges in wh seems like free fall. So realistic was this ride that the Armed Forces used to use it to train paratroopers. The la glimpse we had of Hooker was one of sheer terror. About eighty feet from the bottom a parachute opens and slows t final stages of the descent. We:

dialogues.speaker: THE BOTTOM OF THE RIDE 104
dialogues.text: as the seat settles down to the ground, Macalinski steps like he'd just been for a manicure. Hooker staggers out, not at all sure of his balance.

dialogues.speaker: BOOKER
dialogues.text: So what do ya say, Macalinski?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away) : I'll think about it. What gym you train at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Golding's on Seventh. Where should I call ya? The club?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Forget it, If I want to talk to ya, T'li get in touch with you. Hooker watches them go, leaning on a post for support. On they're safely out of sight, he stumbles over to a trash and throws up. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical waterfront greasy spoon with a horseshoe counte and napkin holders that dispense fortunes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker enters the diner to get something to settle his stomach. The place is pretty empty this time of night. Hooker orders a bicarbonate, While he's waiting, he happe to look across the counter just as a familiar face looks up at him. It's his old friend, Lieutenant Snyder, the Chicago bunco detective. The two men are astonished to. see each other. At first, neither of them moves from his position. -

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: Hi there, Hooker. Remember me?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How could I forget you, Snyder. | What are you doin' in Atlantic City, bringin' in a new disease? Snyder has long since learned to let cracks like that rol off his back. He feigns casualness, but is ready to move at the slightest hint that Hooker is going to flee. Hooke on the other hand, is finely attuned to any sign that Sny may attack. Hooker's bicarbonate is brought to him by the fountain attendant.

dialogues.speaker: ER
dialogues.text: I'm with the federal bunco people now. Came down here to pinch a guy.

dialogues.speaker: _ _, HOOKER
dialogues.text: (drinking his bicarbonate) Well I hope you find him. _ SNYDER . I just did. Didn't expect him to walk right up to me though.

dialogues.speaker: __ HOOKER
dialogues.text: You're bluffin'. The feds got bigger guys to worry about than me.

dialogues.speaker: . SNYDER
dialogues.text: Not this one. I coulda overlooked that three grand in bad notes you slipped me in Chicago, but when you played me for the chump in that Lonnegan caper, that tore it. It was ail I could do to keep Lonnegan from puttin' a bullet in me. I figure if you go up for a ten-year stretch, it might square things up.

dialogues.speaker: . _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: You know it ain't gonna do no good to chase me. I've always been faster than you.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I got the endurance. I been waitin' four years for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder gets up from his stool to make his move. Hooker flips a coin on the counter to pay for the_ bicarbonate a then sprints out the door with Snyder in close pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: racing down the amusement midway with Snyder at his heels both dodging the street vendors and the scattered people still strolling the pier at this hour. Hooker makes for t Fun House, leaping the turnstile much to the surprise of attendant. Snyder flashes his badge as he crashes through curt TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like most forties fun houses, this one consists of a seri of "obstacles" that one must pass through to get out. Onc you're in the progression, you have to go on. There's no turning back. The obstacles are designed to be fun if tak at a deliberate speed. If you're in a hurry, the place ca be treacherous. Neither Hooker nor Snyder are deliberatin

dialogues.speaker: FUN HOUSE ENTRANCE TUNNEL 110
dialogues.text: The first obstacle is a revolving drum just inside the entrance tunnel. It's difficult enough to walk through. But Hooker tries to take it at a dead run. He's thrown down violently and tumbles several times, Snyder is able to grab him for an instant, but is immediately thrown off his feet too. lll ANGLE 111 The two men grapple fiercely, tumbling head over heels, banging off the walls, flailing at each other with arms a legs. Neither is able to establish dominance because of the constant revolving of the drum. Hooker finally kicks himself free and scrambles out on hands and knees. Both men have taken a terrible beating. .

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER TUNNEL IN THE FUN HOUSE 112
dialogues.text: Hooker jumps to his feet and heads into another tunnel, t one pitch dark. Still the two go as fast as they can, in effort to gain ground, crashing from side to side, trippi on things, knocking over the laughing clowns and roaring devils that pop out at them. :  113 114 115

dialogues.speaker: AT A FOUR-LANE SLIDE IN THE FUN HOUSE 113
dialogues.text: Hooker emerges from the tunnel at the top of a four-lane slide. Usually one negotiates the slide by sitting on a burlap sack. Hooker disdains the sack, flinging himself down the slope head first. Both are getting skin burns to go with the bruises they got in the barrel. Neither man i having fun in this house.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FUN HOUSE
dialogues.text: Hooker has his choice of the "Slanted House" or the "Mirr Maze." A good mirror maze is truly a confounding expersen People have been known to get lost in them for upwards of an hour.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE FUN HOUSE
dialogues.text: Snyder charges in after Hooker, and is brought to a quick stop by the sight of sixteen different images of himself. The pace of the chase now changes completely. Snyder makes his way slowly through the maze, painstaking trying to discern the real path from all the reflected on Every once in a while an image of Hooker will flash acros several mirrors, but Snyder has no idea which one to chas It's quiet now, the only sound, the labored breathing of two men. Hooker finally calls to Snyder from another part Q e maze. ¥

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You never shoulda followed me in here, Snyder. I've been through this maze a hundred times.

dialogues.speaker: -SNYDER
dialogues.text: It don't matter what you do, Hooker. I'm not leavin' Atlantic City with- out you.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Guess I might as well give up then. Suddenly, Hooker appears rig t off Snyder's left shoulder He cocks his arm for a punch, but Snyder catches him out the corner of his eye, whirls around, and smashes a might blow to Hooker's gut. Or what he thought was Hooker. Un- fortunately, it's just another mirror image. Hooker, beca of his experience in this maze, knew just where to stand create a single reflection. Snyder's punch splinters the mirror to bits and opens a nasty cut on his head.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 115
dialogues.text: Snyder is an enraged bull now. Several images of Hooker begin to appear in the mirrors. Snyder goes after all of them, wildly clubbing them with his pistol butt, kicking them with his boots, shattering mirror after mirror in a frantic attempt to destroy the real Hooker. Finally all t images of Hooker disappear, and Snyder hears his footstep receding rapidly in the distance. He knows by the time he finds his way out, Hooker will be long gone. He looks bac at the trail of destruction he's left and then slumps bac against the wall in exhaustion. We hold a beat and: cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The store is closed, but Hooker gets in with a key and go back to the "meat locker."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff, Singleton, The Big Ohio, the Tuxedo Kid and Eir are waiting for him. Gondorff has gotten out of his ivory suit, preferring, of course, his undershirt and fedora. However, he's still in his makeup. We see that it only covers from his neck up and from his wrists out. The rest of him is lily-white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it took ya long enough. How'd it go? .

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: He didn't say much. 1 don't know how good a hook I got into him. GONDORFF . What'd he say when you told him about the Kelley fight?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Just kept lookin' at the scenery. Maybe he doesn't hate you - enough yet.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: It's not enough for these guys to hate ya. They gotta see how they can make money offa hatin' ya. He'll figure it out.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: That ain't the worst of it. I ran into Snyder tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What the hell's he doin’ here? HOOKER . He's a fed now. Been failin' his way upward, but he still don't like me any better than he used to.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: You think he knows what we're here for?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Naw, he came for me. Says he's gonna send me up this time.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: You say the word, we all go home. None of us'd like to see you do a stretch.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
