dialogues.text: Forget it. None of us likes the stretch Kid Twist is doin' either. I've stayed away from Snyder this long, I can lose him for another couple weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tired) . Okay, let's knock off for tonight. cut TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late at night now and the street is about deserted. Hooker is making his way home staying in the shadows as m as possible in case Snyder may be patrolling the streets. He passes an apartment building and sees a light on ina third floor window. He stops for a second, considers it and decides to enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: etting off the elevator, an old cage-type, at the third loor. He goes down the hall to door 306 and knocks. The door opens, and there stands Veronica. The radio plays Helen Forrest's "I'm Nobody's Baby."

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hooker, 70 119

dialogues.speaker: __ HOOKER
dialogues.text: Howdy. I was in the neighborhood; 1 thought I'd drop by and say you did a nice job on Macalinski tonight.

dialogues.speaker: ____ VERONICA
dialogues.text: (making no move to invite him in) It was nothin'. Just another con.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: If it was so nothin', why aren't you asleep yet?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Just restless, I guess. tired of standing in the doorway, walks right in, much to the chagrin of Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: . _,. VERONICA
dialogues.text: I didn't invite you in.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I thought you might like some company for a change. I never see you with anybody. Christ, Sheridan, how come you're so hard-nosed all the time? I mean, now that we're even Steven....

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: We ain't never gonna be even Steven, and if I wanted company, I woulda got some. I know ten guys I could call right now and they'd be up here inside a five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: All right, I won't stay long. I know you wanna get back to not worryin!' about the con. Can I have a beer? I'll pay ya for it. Hooker goes in the icebox and gets two bottles of beer. Veronica plunks herself down on the couch, her arms cross She is restless.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Get me one too, Maybe it'll make me tired. If I didn't have to worry about Macalinski seein' me, I could go out dancin' or somethin’.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You could dance here.

dialogues.speaker: . VERONICA
dialogues.text: Not likely. You need a partner.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: You got one.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Aw, c'mon. I used to teach dancin’. I don't dance with just any shlump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: _ (infuriated) You think I can't dance? I happen to be from Chicago, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: You go to high school at all?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Taft.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Taft? I went to Jefferson. Scored two touchdowns on ya in '24. Eighty- five yard punt return. Sixteen yar end run. And I was only a sophomore. If I'd ever gotten to be a junior, no tellin’ how many I mighta scored.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: That don't mean you can dance. Everybody knows a Jaffie couldn't take two steps in a row.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Why would I ask ya to dance if I couldn't dance?

dialogues.speaker: . VERONICA
dialogues.text: You didn't come over to dance. I know what you came up here for. None of the eruye at Jefferson could do that, either.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Not with a Taft broad, anyhow. You were liable to catch somethin’. {going over to .. ., the record player) Sit tight, doll. I'11 show ya who's from Chicago. Hooker searches quickly through some records and finds so thing he likes, Glenn Miller's "In The Mood." He puts it the turntable and drops the needle. He moves a couple cha out of the way to make more room as the intro starts. Veronica can't believe this. :

dialogues.speaker: _ROOKER
dialogues.text: All right, Sheridan. Do your worst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beat comes up and Hooker and Veronica launch into the most knock-down, killer-diller lindy jitterbug we have ev seen, featuring all the great "air steps" and acrobatics early forties could muster. Veronica executes an amazing series of twirls, kicks and jumps that come within inches taking Hooker's head off. Hooker, on the other hand, is a great power dancer, whipping Veronica around like a top, throwing her over his back, around ‘his shoulders and und his legs. They're both dancing fluidly: but with a certai savagery -- each one trying to outdo the other, each one trying to push the dance into steps that the other can't follow. It's a slam-bang two minutes. The Soul Train All- Starts got nothin' on this. The record ends and the dance finishes in a draw. Both Ho and Veronica maintain their nonchalance, like it was a wa in the park, each trying hard to disguise the fact that t gasping for breath. Hooker chugs the last of his beer and picks up his hat.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hope ya get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Yeah, see ya around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CONTINUED i121 Hooker walks quietly out the door. Once he's gone, Veronica sags into a chair, completely wo out, but not a little bit exhilerated. She'll get to slee tonight. ‘I'm nobody's baby, I wonder why. Won't someone hear my plea And please take a chance with me Because I'm nobody's baby now.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same room we saw him in at the beginning of the film. The photographs are still on the wall, but there's now a blank space where Kid Twists's picture once hung. One of Lonnegan's aids, Gelleher, is s owing him a flyer adver- tising the Florian (Hooker)-Kelley fight.

dialogues.speaker: GELLEBER
dialogues.text: Looks like they're gonna use some kinda boxing scam, peddling Hooker as a fighter. I heard they tied into Macalinski last year.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, Scanlon told me about it. Gondorff played him made up like a nigger. Just the thought of what Scanlon told him starts Lonnegan chuckling, Pretty soon he's laughing almost uncontrol abl Gelleher is a little taken aback. He's never seen Lonnega like this before. (barely able to talk) . \ “You know what they did to him?

dialogues.speaker: GELLEHER
dialogues.text: No, what? - Lonnegan is laughing so hard it takes him ten seconds to quiet down enough to tell Gelleher what Gondorff did.

dialogues.speaker: _ LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: They took off his toupee... (breakin up again -..and ripped it!

dialogues.speaker: GELLEHER
dialogues.text: _ (amazed) And ripped? Lonnegan can only nod. He's convulsed with laughter again He pounds the desk with sheer glee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Floyd storms into the room, obviously agitated something. He plunks a copy of the Chicago Tribune down o Lonnegan's desk. :

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Doyle, look at this. That bastard Chicago DA has indicted us. Can you believe them rabbits? For tax eva- sion, the bum. That sucker's lookin! for a lead luncheon.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Don't get excited, Floyd. I knew about it a week ago, We've beat _ that rap before, we'll beat it again.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: But don't you see what this does? The feds'll be all over us. We can't go around killin' Gondorff's people with that much heat on. We'll all end up in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I know all that Floyd. I've been thinkin' about it all week.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: So what do we do? Just let 'em go? (getting worked up and pointing to the flyer) ‘That guy called me Mutt.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: No. (pause) . We get Macalinski to kill ‘em for us.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we're the ones who took it in the shorts. What kinda charge do we get outa this.

dialogues.speaker: __, LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Just the satisfaction of bringing off a con that goes Gondorff one better than he gave us. As good as his game was, it only took our money. So Macalinski pulls the triggers. Dead is dead.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Not to me, it ain't. A guy is always deader when I kill: him. How do you know Macalinski'll do it? :

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Don't worry about Macalinski. I'll give him a reason. There's only one guy in this world I fear more than him.

dialogues.speaker: GELLEHER
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Me. This last remark is lost on Floyd. He's totally absorbed the flyer on Hooker's fight.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD ,
dialogues.text: Christ, Mutt and Jeff. I hate fuckin' Mutt and Jeff. If I was in the ring with this guy, I'd punch him a new ace. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: detailing Hooker's somewhat reluctant training for the Ke fight. We see shots of him: 1. skipping rope; 2. shadow boxing in front of a mirror; 3. practicing his crossing punches on the ‘punch catchers' held by The Big Ohio; 4. working the speed bag. He has a little trouble with this last one, as his timing is not yet sharp. All of this training is done under the supervision of The Ohio, who seems to be very knowledgeable about fighting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We come out of the montage with Hooker throwing combinati into the heavy bag. lorff (in black face and the ivory suit) and The Big Ohio are watching him. Hooker is sweati profusely and obviously getting a little tired. The rest the gym is filled with confidence men, all dressed out as fighters and trainers, but at this point, they're just si ting around shooting the breeze.

dialogues.speaker: _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: (gasping) How much longer?

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: (looking at his stopwatch) Minute and a half.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 125
dialogues.text: That's too long. Hooker drops his arms and stops punching GONDORFF ‘ C'mon, you'll never get in shape that way.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? I'm gonna be down anyway.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you gotta make it look good. Macalinski’s gonna know somethin's wrong if you fast go out there and get pulverized.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How good is this guy Kelley?

dialogues.speaker: _.., GONDORFF
dialogues.text: (mimicking Hooker ) . What difference does it make? You're gonna lie down anyway. HOOKER . Yeah, but I wanta lie down with my head on.

dialogues.speaker: _.,, GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Then keep hittin' the bag. Suddenly Eirie comes rushing into the gym. . .. EIRIE . Macalinski just drove up outside. GONDORFF . Okay, everybody, let's get movin’! Immediately all the previously inert confidence men sprin their feet and begin the various rigors of training. Some work the speed bags and heavy bags, some get rubdowns, ot shadowbox. The Tuxedo Kid takes up a position next to Gondorff, dressed in a gaudy, checkered sport coat. We know this disguise is causing him great pain.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Ohio, get in the ring and spar a few rounds with Hooker. And Ohio.... h THE BIG OHIO Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Get hit a lot.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hooker and The Big Ohio quickly put on their protective h lear and jump into the ring. Macalinski enters the gym wi ee of the bodyguards, He surveys the scene a second and then spots Hooker sparring in the ring. He comes over to watch, standing a couple feet behind Gondorff and the Tux Kid, who pretend not to know he's there. Up in the ring, Hooker is punching The Big Ohio all over lot, The Big Ohio, of course, exaggerating the impact of every blow. Finally Hooker delivers a left hook, and The Big Ohio, in a tour de force of acrobatics, flips over th ropes and clean out of the ring. Gondorff calls Hooker an pretends to be furious with hin.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What the hell do ya think you're doin'? I told you not to show that left hook. What if some sports- writer had seen that? You think they'd ever believe you could lose to Dann Kelley on the square with a left hook like that?

dialogues.speaker: , _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I just forget my self. None of this has been lost on Macalinski's ears. The Big meanwhile, is staggering to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: (dazed) Sorry Berrigan, I've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, all right. (shouting up to Hooker) . Bobby, that's enough for a while. Hooker climbs out of the ring and winks as he walks past Macalinski. Gondorff turns around and for the first time is face to face with Macalinski. 4 _  GONDORFF . Well, if it ain't Macalinski. You ever find that Queen?

dialogues.speaker: . __ MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, it was in my sleeve. (indicating Gondorff's suit) I found it ‘cause I change my clothes now and then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: o~ 125 CONTINUED - 3 125

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Oh, this isn't the same suit you saw me in. I got seven or eight of these. Macalinski didn't resally come to talk fashion. MACALINSKI . Your boy looks pretty good, Berrigan. GONDORFF . Yeah, doesn't he though. Let me give you a tip Macalinski. Don't tell . anybody ‘cause I wanna keep the odds down, but this kid is gonna murder Kelley. You'd be smart to get some money down on him.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: I wouldn'ta thought you'd be so interested in puttin’ me onto a good thing.

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I believe in lettin’ bygones by bygones, a know what I mean? I don't mind oo loin’ guys like you a favor. 1 figure you can use a break now and then. I wouldn't steer you wrong, Macalinski. you can't lost with a bundle on this id.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Is that right? Thanks, Berrigan. I appreciate it. {with sarcasm, sweeping his hand around the gym) - Well, I'll leave ya to tend to all your various business interests.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, by the way, Lola sends her love. Macalinski suppresses the urge to strangle Gondorff, and leaves the gym with his guard dogs. On the way out, he passes Hooker toweling off.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (out of the side o of his mouth) Meet me at the Bluebird tonight at nine o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hooker nods, and Macalinski disappears down the stairs. Gondorff looks over to Hooker for some sign. Hooker gives him both thumbs up. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Hooker walking through the club and back to. Macalinski's office. He knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of Macalinski's goons opens it and immediately yanks Hooker inside and throws him up against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: . . HOOKER
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: We called the Jersey Boxing Commission, they never heard of Bobby Florian. HOOKER . . That's ‘cause I done all my fightin’ in California. . (pulling a piece of paper out of his wallet Here, here's my license. Macalinski looks it over carefully, and then puts it in h pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: _ (to his goon) All right, let him go. Hooker sinks into a chair opposite Macalinski's desk, sti little shaken.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Your owner is even lower than I thought he was. He tried to get me to put money on you, even though he's told ya to take a dive.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: That's 'cause he wants ya to lose your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: How much is he puttin' on Kelley? HOOKER . Two hundred grand maybe. That ain't the only way he wins though. Remember the guy in the checked coat that was with ‘im in the ? That's Harry Chandler, his bookie friend. The odds on the fight are dead even all over town, except Harry's givin' two- to-one on Kelley to get people to bet on me at his book.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Does he know you're supposed to dump the fight?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hell, yes. He builds up a big bunch a bets on me and he and Berrigan split the take. Berrigan gets it comin' and goin' and I don't get nothing but a_ one line story that says Bobby Florian went on his butt when Danny Kelley breathed on him too hard. Berrigan takes it on the lam to the Bahamas and I wind up sellin' pencils. I tell ya, if I don't throw s fight, it's gonna cost Chandler and Berrigan plenty.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: And whoever bets on you at Chandler's odds is gonna win plenty. . HOOKER . That's right. That's what I'm doin' with my dough. i'm havin' a friend bet it, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Florian, I wanta see ya fight.

dialogues.speaker: _ _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: You saw me fight today.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: I mean against somebody good. HOOKER . Why? All I'm askin' for is protection.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: You ain't gonna get any unless I see you fight.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: But that's impossible. Berrigan'll never let me fight before the Kelley match.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: He won't know about it. We'll do it at another gym. :

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: What if I get cut or somethin'?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: You won't if you're any good, and if you ain't, you might as well take that dive anyway. I'l] pick you up to- morrow morning at ten. The bus station. Hooker wants to protest some more, but he's hustled out o the room before he gets a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks through the club, wondering what the hell to do cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker comes out of the club and starts walking up the st when he catches sight of someone getting out of a car up It's Snyder. Hooker turns and takes off down the pier. Sn immediately gives chase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker heads for the "Cyclone Racer", the giant roller co He hops in the first car, which is empty, and shouts to t operator, whom he knows well.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Get this baby goin', Georgie. And do me a favor. Give me a slow-down on the seventh turn.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: You got it, Hooker.  131 132 133 134 135

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie activates the tow mechanism and the car starts it slow ascent of the first hill as Snyder arrives. He con- siders getting in a car and going after Hooker, but then thinks better of it. He's no fool, that Snyder.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Oh no ya don't, Hooker. You're not suckerin' me into this one. (to Georgie) Hey buddy, these cars have gotta come right back to here, don't they? There's no other place then can go, right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: That's right, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: (breaking into a smile) You hung yourself this time, Hooker. He leans back against the railing, in delicious anticipat of Hooker's return. We:

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER 132
dialogues.text: barrelling down the chutes and whipping through the curve the Cyclone Racer. It's a helluva ride and the camera sho take it for a while. Suddenly, as the car is reaching the of another hill, we: cur TO

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S CAR 133
dialogues.text: which slow appreciably as it goes into the turn. Hooker j out and grabs onto the wooden scaffolding as the car bare makes it around the corner and starts down the hill. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE AGAIN 134
dialogues.text: He release the lever, and we see a hint of a smile on his face, which is a first for Georgie. We:

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER 135
dialogues.text: climbing down the outside of the scaffolding. None of thi is visible to Snyder through the maze of track and wood t makes up the rollers coaster. Finally we: Cut TO  136 137

dialogues.speaker: THE CAR
dialogues.text: as it comes around the last turn and slows into the loadi area. Snyder watches it all the way in. We see his face turn to putty. He can't believe the car is empty Once it's stopped, he frantically searches under and ind every seat for some sign of Hooker. Finally he turns to Georgie

dialogues.speaker: . SNYDER
dialogues.text: What happened to the guy that was in here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGIE
dialogues.text: (completely deadpan) Probably fell off and killed himself. Snyder knows Georgie's screwed him some way, but he doesn know - He turns to go look for Hooker and finds himself face to face with Floyd. Eveni ynde: Doyle L ‘d ening, S' re @ Lonnegan like a few words with ya. snyder manages a weak nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder is ushered in by Floyd and Gelleher. He's a little unsettled by the pictures on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Hello, Snyder. What are you doin’ in Atlantic City?

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: I'm on vacation. Got a couple weeks, thought I'd....

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: {cutting him off) You shouldn't tell me lies like that, Snyder, when things between us are 80 sore. Floyd saw you chasin' Johnny Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: Okay, I was.chasin' him. I came down here to take him back to Chicago. To face trial for connin'

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 137
dialogues.text: SNYDER (Cont'd) you. I should think that would make you happy. Fat chance.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I want you to lay off Hooker. He's workin’ a con here that's gonna make me back all the money he ever took from me. I don't want anything to discourage him.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: Hey look, I'm a fed now, I can't just turn my back on this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: All right, then we'll make you a deal. You leave Hooker alone and I'll tell you where they're going to split up the score. That way you can come in and pinch all of 'em -- the biggest confidence bust in New Jersey history. Snyder tries to play the brinksman.

dialogues.speaker: . SNYDER
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'11 think about it.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (in no mood for further negotiation) There's nothin' to think about. You either take the deal, or go after Hooker and hope you get him before one of my guys gets you.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: You can't muscle me. I got the U.S. Government behind me.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I don't care if you got the U.s. Marines behind you. You screw up this con and all your government service'll get you is a nice funeral. Snyder decides maybe he'll soften his line a little.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: How do you know when they're gonna make the split?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I got my sources.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: All right. 1'11 play ball. (with false bravado) But you better come up with that info. Snyder turns and walks out the door. Lonnegan lets him go He's not expecting anymore trouble. cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lights in the gyn are off as Hooker and Eirie walk th to the lighted office section. .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff lies stretched out on a couch -- his hat on his He stirs and sits up as Hooker and Eirie enter.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: What happened tonight?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I had to lam it from Snyder again. He's got that pier staked out on me.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: All right, then, stay off of it from now on. What about Macalinski?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: He threw us a curve. He wants to see ~ me fight somebody other than the Ohio. I don't know who it is, but he's takin' me to another gym to- morrow.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Christ, after we go to all the trouble to build one of our own.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: What are we gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Well, I wouldn't worry too much about it. We oughta be able to come up with something. We can tell by Gondorff's look that, at this point, he ha no idea what that might be. We hold a beat, and:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Macalinski looking over the boxing license he took from Hooker the night before. Under the name California Boxing Commission, he sees a phone number. He picks up th phone and dials it. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: answering a phone. Intercut with Macalinski as necessary.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Hello, California Boxing Commission. MACALINSKi Yeah, I'd like some information on a guy named Bobby Florian.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Hold on one moment, please. 1'1) transfer you to the Records Department. - Billie pushes the button down a couple times to indicate she's transferring the call, and then comes on the line again with a different voice.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: (most officiously) Miss Deering, Records Department.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: I'd like to know what you got on a Bobby Florian. He's a middleweight.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Just a minute, please. Billie holds a few beats and then pretends to be reading from a file. .
Florian, Bobby. Age twenty-seven. Height six feet. Weight....

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (impatient) Skip all that. What's his record?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: His record? Let me look down here. Twelve wins, eight by knockout as an amateur. No losses. As a profes- sional, seven wins all by knockout, and one defeat. That was to Benny Alvarado at the Olympic Auditorium on the 16th of July last year.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Thanks lady, that'll do it. Macalinski hangs up and turns to the bodyguard who slamme Hooker up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: He's on the level. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE 142
dialogues.text: She hangs up the phone and gives the okay sign to Gondorf who's been in the room with her the whole time. curt To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is standing on the corner as Macalinski's limousin pulls up. The door is opened and Hooker gets in. He's carrying a gym bag with all his boxing gear in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car pulls away as Hooker settles in beside Macalinski

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: How do you feel today, kid?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Good. (pointing to a bruiser on the other side of him) I'm puttin' ya in with Tony here. Tony Savitt, meet Bobby Florian. Tony used to be the number one middleweight contender. He'll give ya a tussle.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 144
dialogues.text: Tony flashes Hooker a wide smile. We can tell he's ready to give Hooker more than a tussle. Hooker tries to smile back, but his mouth is a little dry and it's hard to stre it.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Where we gonna fight?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: The Eighth Street Gym. It's outta the way. Hardly anybody goes there. Hooker nods and casually puts his arm out of the window l he's going to rest his hand on the roof. Instead we see h hold up two fingers. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: following behind Macalinski. Eirie is driving. Gordorff i also in front, The Big Ohio in the back.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: (eyes glued to Hooker's . hand) Two fingers. That's the Eighth Street Gym. Step on it, Eirie. Gondorff then puts his arm out the window, turns to the r and waves two fingers at the cars following him. We see that at least eight of them are filled with confidence sk dressed out, as usual, as boxers and trainers. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is going through his gym bag, making sure he's got everything. He pulls out a boxing shoe. The laces are completely frazzled.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (to the driver) Stop at this five and dime up here, will ya. I gotta get some new laces for these things. The driver looks to Macalinski to see if it's okay. Macalinski shrugs and nods his head. As the car pulls ove Gondorff's car goes speeding by. :

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: What's Hooker doin'?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Giving us a little more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car pulls up in front of the gym. Billie and Singleton get out carrying a large portrait camera. Gondorff's car leads the rest of his armada around to the rear of the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie goes inside while Singleton sets up his camera out front. She asks for the owner of the place and is shown i the office of a paunchy old hacker named Pyle. Pyle has t Customary pretention of one who has nothing to be pretent out.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm from Life Magazine. I called you earlier?

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: I don't remember no call.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: But you must. We're doing an eight- page spread on the great boxing gymnasiums in the country. I thought sure it was this one... (pause) Maybe it's that one across town. Turner's Gym. Pyle is not about to let this opportunity get away. The Eighth Street Gym is not exactly world famous. It's not even city famous.

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: Naw, this is the right one, lady. Turner's is a dump. I remember you now. We've had more champions outta here than you can shake a stick at. Ain't that right, Egan? Egan is Pyle's mousy little assistant.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: (trying to remember one) Oh yeah, lots of ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Good. I'd like to get started right away. If you could get everybody out in front of the gym, I'd appreciate it. Sort of using the gym as a back- drop. .

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: Why do we need everybody?

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: That's the way we did it for the Main Street Gym in Los Angeles and Paterson's in Philadelphia.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: (impressed as 11) Jees, we're gonna be in there with the Main Street and Paterson's?

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: Well, I guess if they can do it, we can.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Mr. Pyle, you'll be right out in front.

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: Okay, Egan, get everybody out.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We'll also need some jump ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Egan rushes into the gym.

dialogues.speaker: EGAN
dialogues.text: Okay, everybody, drop what you're doin' and come on out front. We're gonna have our pictures in Life Magazine. And bring your’ ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's some grumbling and complaining, but everyone file out. Once the gym is cleared, Gondorff and his men pour i through the rear door and immediately fill the place with activity. . cut To  151 152 153

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're getting near the gym.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Hold it.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: What for? The car comes to a jolting stop.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I know the door guard out front. We don't want him blabbin' to Berrigan. Use the alley.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (to his driver) Do what he says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver pulls down the alley and into the back of the thus prohibiting them from seeing what's going on out fro

dialogues.speaker: INT, EIGHTH STREET GYM
dialogues.text: Hooker, Macalinski, Savitt and the bodyguards enter throu the rear door. They are, of course, met with the sight of fighters training everywhere. Gondorff comes over to gree them: Because Macalinski has never seen him without black face, he wouldn't recognize him. Gondorff also alters his voice slightly.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORF
dialogues.text: Can I help you? I'm the- manager here, Lonny Pyle.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: We'd like to use your ring for a bit. (pointing ~ to Hooker) I wanna test this boy here a little.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Well, we got the number three middle- weight contender in here. He's lookin' for some work. Why don't you throw your boy in with him?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (indicating Savitt) No, I brought my own guy.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 153
dialogues.text: Gondorff had not expected this. Both he and Hooker are looking a little pale right now.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Yeah. He shouts over to The Big Ohio, who's disguised in a hair piece and moustache.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Hey, Joey... (indicating Savitt) ++.tape this guy up, will ya. (indicating Hooker) I'll tape the other guy. The Big Ohio walks off to one dressing room with Savitt. Gondorff and Hooker go off to the other one, followed by Eirie.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: What the hell we gonna do now?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: _ Just leave it to me. Okay, Eirie, get that other guy's mouthpiece out of his bag and bring it to me. Eirie leaves to carry out his assignment as Gondorff snap a role of tape. We: cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Singleton has got his first shot posed. The fighters are lined up in a row, with their dukes up and menacing sneer their faces. Behind them stand the trainers, each with a towel over his arm and one hand on his fighter's shoulder Out in front of all this stands Pyle, his arms dramatical crossed, the moulder of men. Next to him is Egan, sportin the most shit-eating grin we've ever seen. Singleton ducks under the black cloth, tells everybody to still and snaps his picture. Some of the fighters turn to back into the gym, but Billie stops them.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, now we'll do an action one. The fighters shake their heads, but they cooperate. cUuT TO  155 156 157

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff is busily taping Hooker's hands. Much to Hooker' amazenent, he pulls out a roll of nickels and tapes that looker's fist. You can't do this for a real fight. They always check the tape. Believe me, if he runs into that hand, he'll stay down.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what am I supposed to do with everything he's owin' while I'm waitin' for him to run into it? Eirie bursts into the room with Savitt's mouthpiece. GONDOREF . There's a bottle of methyl chloride over there. Let the mouthpiece soak in it a while, Once Savitt gets some of that in him, he won't e able to walk let alone fight. We go to Hooker. He has his doubts. a . cut TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie is rehearsing her action shot. It calls for all of fighters to skip rope in unison, under the watchful eye o their trainers while Pyle and Egan, of course, maintain t standard poses out front. None of this is visible from inside, because, like all gymnasiums, the windows are fro Billie gives the signal to begin and all the fighters sta skipping, but several are out of sync. Billie stops them.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: No, no, no. Let's try it again. And remember, it's gotta be together. On the beat now. Ready. One, two, three.... They all begin skipping again. This time only one guy is out of step. The bther fighters give hin holy hell. “They tired and y wanna get s thing right, dammit. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker and Savitt, their gloves and protective headgear o are entering the ring. Macalinski settles back to watch.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: (to Savitt) You got a mouthpiece?

dialogues.speaker: SAVITT
dialogues.text: Couldn't find it. Don't make no difference, I won't need it. Sorry pal, nobody fights in this gym without a mouthpiece. Eirie get this boy a gourbp ioe. ‘ Eirie, of course, produces the one that's been soaking in methyi chloride. Gondorff jams it into Savitt's mouth, wh winces at the taste. . . _SAVITT . Christ, this thing tastes terrible.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: That's just the antiseptic we use. What would you rather have, tuber- culosis? Savitt is pretty sure he'd rather not have tuberculosis. begins to do a little shadowboxing as does Hooker on the other side. Even as he dances, Savitt begins to shake his head a little, as if to clear it. Gondorff decides it's t start. He claps his hands and the two fighters come out. Hooker immediately begins dancing away from Savitt, reali that Savitt is getting groggy. Savitt stalks him and whip out a few combinations, but Hooker is staying so far away that they do no damage.

dialogues.speaker: SAVITT
dialogues.text: What's the matter, you scare of me, Florian?

dialogues.speaker: _ HOOKER
dialogues.text: Just wanna give my legs some work before I put you away. Hooker continues to back away as Savitt stalks him all ov the ring. Macalinski doesn't like what he's seeing. . MACALINSKI . c'mon, Florian, fight, for chrissake. Savitt decides he's had enough of this, too. He backs Hoo into a corner and comes in to finish him off. Unfortunate the methyl chloride is really getting to him now. He: thr

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: two wild haymakers which miss Hooker by a foot. Savitt is shaking his head and blinking his eyes now. He looks read to fall asleep. Realizing his opportunity, Hooker steps inside and smashes the right to Savitt's stomach. Savitt doubles up, although he was probably getting ready to fal down anyway. Then Hooker cranks up and unleashes his hard right to Savitt's chin. Savitt goes down and out like a l Macalinski is amazed. He comes up to Hooker as he starts untie his gloves. _. MACALINSKI . Nice work, kid. I didn't know you had that kinda power. Get your- self a shower and we'll go.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER _
dialogues.text: Don't need a shower. Didn't even work up a sweat. I'll just get the gloves off and be right out. As Hooker goes off to the dressing room, Gondorff comes o to Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: . _ GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I been in this business thirty years and I ain't never seen a guy with a punch like that. Where'd you find that kid? Macalinski isn't talking. He just smiles and walks away. Meanwhile the bodyguards are dragging Savitt out to the c Once they're all outside, Gondorff turns to all the gang a more than satisfied smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: emerging from the back door and getting into the limousin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savitt is propped up in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How's Savitt?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: He's awake, but he still don't know where he is. The limousine pulls out and we: cur TO  159 160 161 162

dialogues.speaker: THE FRONT OF THE GYM AGAIN 159
dialogues.text: Billie is ready for yet another run-through. We can tell troops are restless. BILLIE . All right, everybody. We'll try it just once more. This is the time we get it right, okay? One, two, three.... The fighters once again begin skipping madly. This time, however, it's perfect. Fifteen grown men s: pping their a off in perfect time, each rope coming around at the same each man jumping up and down in the same rhythm. It's a t tally ridiculous sight.

dialogues.speaker: SINGLETON AND BILLIE 160
dialogues.text: Singleton snaps the pictures as Billie notices Gondorff a the others driving away.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: Okay, guys, that's a keeper. Thanks for your cooperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fighters and trainers drag back into the gym. Singlet folds up his camera and he and Billie start for their car Pyle, however, buttonholes them.

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: When's this spread gonne hit the stands? BILLIE . In a couple weeks. You be watchin’ for it

dialogues.speaker: PYLE
dialogues.text: Be sure you spell my name right. It's Pyle. P+Y-L-E. Billie nods. She'll be sure and get that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as it moves through the city.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: You got your protection Florian. Do what you want to Kelley.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Kelley'll be ever easier than Savitt here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The limousine pulls up in front of the bus terminal and H gets out.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: One more thing. Where do I find- this guy Chandler?

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: One eighteen North Cumberland. Ask to see some Webster jade.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: See ya at the fights. The limousine pulls away from the curb. Savitt is coming of it somewhat now.

dialogues.speaker: _SAVITT
dialogues.text: Seemed to me like I was goin' down before he even hit me.

dialogues.speaker: ___MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (humoring him) Sure, Tony, sure. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vernoica is sitting quietly on the couch, sipping some te listening to Mary Lou Williams' version of "He's Funny Th Way. . 'I never had nothin! No one to care That's why I seem To have more than my share. I got a man : Who's crazy for me He's Funny That Way.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock at the door. Veronica goes to answer it. seems almost excited about who might be there. She opens

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 165
dialogues.text: door to find Macalinski and two of his goons standing in Obviously, this wasn't who she was hoping for.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Just wanted to give you my personal regards, Lola. I woulda done it sooner, but it took a while to find you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that, he drives a vicious punch into Veronica's stom As she stumbles forward, he rears back and blasts her in face, knocking her all the way across the room and over a table. She lies unconscious on the floor. We hold on her as the lights go out, the door closes and we hear footste disappear down the stairs. We're left with the plaintive notes of Mary Lou Williams' piano. cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's doing much the same thing Veronica has been doin only in accordance with his tastes, he's drinking beer an listening to something a little more upbeat. Something li Liltin' Martha Tilton's "The Lady is a Tramp." Suddenly, Hooker gets a knock on his door. Unlike Vernoica, he imme ately expects the worst. Unlike Veronica, he doesn't get He opens the door and she staggers in, her nose swollen o one side and a huge shiner on her right eye.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Jesus, what happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: the couch) . I forgot to put on my makeup. This is the way I really look.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: (in no mood for flippancy) Who was it, Veronica? oo, VERONICA Macalinski. He thinks I oughta be payin' more attention to him. You think I could have a beer? You owe me one.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: (offering his) Here, finish this one.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 167
dialogues.text: Veronica takes a long, slow drink. Hooker just gazes at h a minute. She becomes aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: What are you lookin' at? HOOKER ; I don't know. I'm just surprised you came over here, that's all. I mean, you coulda called one of your ten guys. VERONICA . I would of, but I don't really like any of 'em and you were closer. Some- times on a night like this, you wonder if everybody else doesn't like you as much as you don't like them. (pause) How about it, Hooker? How much don't you like me? Veronica asks this question with real concern. She's not being coy. Hooker leans forward and kisses her tenderly o all the bruised areas of her face. He doesn't like her ju fine. Veronica is not at all upset by this response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I could stick around here a while?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: . VERONICA
dialogues.text: Just until I get proper medical attention.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: What if I said no?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: (lying) I'd find somebody else. She reaches up for his head and brings it down to her. Th kiss with all the longing of strangers and the intimacy o lovers, for what will obviously not be the last time toni 'I_get too hungry for dinner at eight I like the theatre but never come late. I never bother with people I hate. That's why the Lady is a Tramp.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: I don't like crap games with barons and earls . . Won't 99 to Harlem in ermine and pearls. Won't dish the dirt with the rest of the girls. . That's why the Lady is a Tramp.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macalinski's limousine pulls up outside a one-story build that has Chandler Import Co. written on its front window. Macalinski, carrying a large leather bag, goes inside wit his usual compliment of bodyguards, and is greeted by a receptionist. It's Billie.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'd like some Webster jade.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: You'll have to see Mr. Chandler’ about that. Second door on your , right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Macalinski and his boys go through a door with Chandler's name on it. The Tuxedo Kid is inside, once again decked o in that checked sport coat. His office however is well ordered and rather fancy, as befits his status as an "importer."

dialogues.speaker: , MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (offerin s hand Chandler. My name's Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, didn't I see you in Goldings’ Gym once?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was down there to have a look at Bobby Florian. I'd like to put a little money on him. They tell me you're in a betting mood. . TUXEDO KID . ‘I'm giving two to one against him. I don't think the kid's got a chance. How wrong do you think I am?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 170
dialogues.text: Macalinski opens his leather bag. It's bursting with mone

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: About four hundred grand worth.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: That's a lotta potatoes, Macalinski. Most books wouldn't take that bet, but then most books aren't sporting men either. Me, I like to live - dangerous. I take risks the others won't take, ‘cause that's what life is all about, ain't it, Macalinski? Macalinski is disgusted by this false declaration of cour 2 but he grits his teeth and says:

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's what it's all about all right. : The Tuxedo Kid leans forward and speaks into an intercom his desk.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID .,
dialogues.text: Jerry, I'm sending in a Mr. Macalinski with a big bet on Florian. Take his money and give him a-free drink. He's a real sportsman. The Tuxedo Kid shows Macalinski to a door in the back of office. The two shake hands. TUXEDO KID. Nice to meet ya, Mr. Macalinski. Come back and see us again. Macalinksi and his boys go through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They find themselves in a plush betting parlor, complete odds board, telephone operators, cashier's window and bar It's similar to the one Gondorff set up in "The Sting" on on a smaller scale, and instead of pictures of horses it features pictures of fighters. Macalinski's boys are im- pressed.

dialogues.speaker: BODYGUARD
dialogues.text: Gee, this guy's pretty well set up.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: He won't be after tonight. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The suitcases are snapped open. Each one is filled to the brim with hundred dollar bills. Camera back to reveal Lonnegan and Floyd,

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: There it is. A million bucks. This guy Kelley better be a sure bet. I'd hate to see that kinda green disappear.

dialogues.speaker: . _LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: We'll find out in a few minutes. Scanlon's on the phone in the other room. There's a knock on the door, and immediately Lonnegan clo the cases. A Guard pokes his head in. Snyder's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send him in. Synder swaggers in with the self-importance typical of hi

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I assume you're here for your information.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: That's right. Toni t's the night. 1 called eight agents into town for this bust. They're gonna be pretty burned up if I don't deliver.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: You can relax, Snyder, I never go back on a. deal. ‘There's a Chinese market down Vermont near 6th. In the back are three meat lockers. The middie one isn't a meat locker at all. It's a meeting room. That's where they're gonna make the split. Snyder is amazed that Lonnegan could discover such a well organized hideout.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: You mind tellin’ me how you find out stuff like this?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I got a source.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think I could use it sometime?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Why don't you ask for yourself? (calling into e other room) Scanlon. “you off the phone yet? We hear a Voice 0.s. as another figure enters the room.

dialogues.speaker: ., VOICE
dialogues.text: Yeah, what is it? The Voice is familiar. The camera moves to reveal that th person is even more familiar. To our amazement, it's Vero

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan delights in Snyder's surprise that the source is woman.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (making the introduction) Camille Scanlon, Agent Snyder. Snyder says he'd like to make use of your services someday.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: (the ice maiden) All it takes is money.

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: (referring to her shiner Looks like you paid a price for what you found out.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: (hard as nails) - I'll get whatever I paid back, and then some.

dialogues.speaker: __ SNYDER
dialogues.text: (taking his leave . Well, Lonnegan, it was nice doin’ business with ya. Someday when I'm bureau chief, maybe I can return the favor. (reluctantly) You know, it's too bad we're on opposite sides of the law. The government could use a guy like you. Lonnegan smiles. He's real thrilled that Snyder thinks so highly of him. Once Snyder's out the door, Lonnegan turns to Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: What's the word on Macalinski?

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: He went for four hundred grand on Hooker. Hooker just told me on the phone that he's dumpin' the fight as soon as it doesn't look too phony. You can put your million on Kelley any time you want. Lonnegan is really proud of himself now.

dialogues.speaker: _. _LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: You see how it all works now, Floyd? At even money, we not only get back the five hi ed grand we lost, but we get another half million in the bargain. Meetin' Henry Gondorff turns out to be the best thing that ever happened to us.

dialogues.speaker: VERONICA
dialogues.text: Well, I gotta get ready to go to the fight with Gondorff. You owe me a hundred grand Lonnegan. I'11 be leavin' early. I don't wanta be caught with Gondorff's boys when Macalinski sees Hooker take the count. Without hesitation, Lonnegan reaches into his desk, pulls out the money and hands it to her. She counts it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: You earned every penny of it. I wish I had ten more like you. Veronica smiles at Floyd, who didn't appreciate this last comment too much.

dialogues.speaker: ___ VERONICA
dialogues.text: » (heading . for the door) | Enjoy yourselves tonight. If I'm even in Chicago, I'll drop by and you can tell me about it. Lonnegan nods good-bye and Veronica is let out the door. Floyd is struggling hard with a thought.

dialogues.speaker: _,, _ FLOYD
dialogues.text: There's still one thing I don't get. How come you told Snyder where they're gonna be meetin'?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: ‘Cause there's no chance they'll ever get there. Macalinski'll see to that once I tell him they conned him. (savoring the thought ) . Of course, that won't be until it's too late for him to deny it. Come on. Lonnegan picks up one of the suitcases, Floyd the other, they exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although an improvement over the Jersey Garden, the Still is no fabulous forum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker is having his hands taped by The Big Ohio. Gondorf looks on, made up as Ivory Berrigan again. Eirie is pacin around the room, more nervous than anybody.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: All right. How good do I gotta feel to get knocked out?

dialogues.speaker: . GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I don't want ya to go out till at least the third round if you can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I can't last that long?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Just do the best you can. You might surprise yourself and go four or five.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I don't wanna surprise myself. I wanta go out there and get creamed early.

dialogues.speaker: GONDOREF
dialogues.text: I told ya, Hooker, this has gotta look convincing. If you just fall over the first time he grazes ya, Macalinski will know he's been had __ and we'll never get outta the building alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan's limousine drives up to the building entrance a stops. Lonnegan, Floyd, and a bodyguard carrying the two suitcases filled with money exit the car and enter the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billie is closing up for the night.

dialogues.speaker: BILLIE
dialogues.text: We're closed.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I know. He continues, without slowing, across the office and into "Chandler's" inner office, followed closely by Floyd and bodyguard. Billie picks up a telephone and presses a butt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A red Light winks next to a telephone which is picked up the Tuxedo Kid.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Yeah... okay. He turns to the room full of grifters. .

dialogues.speaker: . TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Look alive. We got company. The door bangs open and Lonnegan, Floyd and the bodyguard enter. The Tuxedo Kid hangs up the phone slowly.

dialogues.speaker: .__,., TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: My receptionist said we were closed.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I'd like to lay a bet on Kelley to win tonight. Even money.

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Too late. The fight's already started.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: It's nine-fifteen. The fight won't start for another fifteen, twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: . KID
dialogues.text: (to Cashier) Check the arena. The Cashier picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (to Tuxedo Kid) .. Don't I know you from somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: (sweating) . I got an ordinary lookin’ face,
(carefully) Lonnegan. Doyle Lonnegan. The Cashier hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Mr. Chandler? The fight hasn't started yet.

dialogues.speaker: __ TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: Well, you're in luck, Mr. ..Lonnegan? How much did you want to bet? oo. LONNEGAN One million dollars. On Kelley. To win. Even odds.

dialogues.speaker: , TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: What?! That's impossible. 1 can't....

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (grabbing Tuxedo Kid's jacket lapels) . You can. And will. And now. The Tuxedo Kid's eyes go to Floyd's hand inside his coat pocket -- then to Lonnegan's pugnacious expression. He wi

dialogues.speaker: TUXEDO KID
dialogues.text: My boss'1] kill me.... He looks to the Cashier. TUXEDO KID . Count Mr. Lonnegan's money and write him a receipt.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: (to bodyguard) . Stay here. Be first at the cashier's win “4 + I wouldn't want them to run short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A badly beaten fighter is. half-carried into the dressing Hooker watches as the fighter is deposited on a table.

dialogues.speaker: . ., THE BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: Time to go, kid. The Big Ohio pushes on Hooker's gloves and we:

dialogues.speaker: STILLMAN AUDITORIUM
dialogues.text: making their way to their seats in different areas of the arena. Macalinski is down close to ringside. Lonnegan is across the way and up avout fifteen rows. cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as he climbs through the ropes and into the ring. He look across at Danny Kelley, who gives him a warm sneer. Hooke sneers back, but his heart isn't in it. Both fighters do little shadow boxing as the Ying Announcer grabs the mike

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to tonight's program of boxing at the Stillman Auditorium. We begin a seven round semimain. On my right, wearing the red trunks and weighing in at 172, that fine Irish puncher, Danny Kelley. Cheers for Kelley as he makes his rounds.

dialogues.speaker: _ ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: And to my left in the black trunks and weighing in at 171, the kid from California, Bobby Florian. Hooker dances out into the ring, hands held above his hea

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: Floyd is disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: Look at the bum jumpin' around. Like he was actually gonna make a fight of it, the cake-eater.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: C'mon, Floyd. It's time to give Macalinski the bad news.

dialogues.speaker: FLOYD
dialogues.text: You better talk fast. Hooker may not last more than thirty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: WITH LONNEGAN 183
dialogues.text: The referee has finished giving instructions to the fight as Lonnegan makes his way over to where Macalinski is sit  184 185

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING . 184
dialogues.text: The bell rings and the fighters come out. Hooker's plan i obvious immediately -- to stay as far away from Kelley as possible. Kelley, however, bores right in and whips out t jabs which gnap Hooker's head back, but Hooker narrowly manages to duck the right cross that follows. IN THE STANDS - ON MACALINSKI 185 — up in the stands, Macalinski looks on tensely, as Lonnega slides in next to him.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Howdy, Carlo.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Lonnegan. What are you doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Just takin' a little vacation in the sun. Who you got your money on?

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Florian. He's a hell of a puncher.

dialogues.speaker: __LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: How much you got on him?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Four hundred grand. Lonnegan whistles in mock surprise.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (defending his be I've seen him. I know what he can do.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: So do I. He conned me outta five hundred grand four years ago.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: (incredulous What are you talkin’ about?

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: He's no fighter. Never has been. Name's Johnny Hooker. He's been a grifter around Chicago for years.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 185
dialogues.text: _LONNEGAN (Cont'd) He's goin' on his hynie here in a couple minutes. MACALINSKI . But what about his manager, Berrigan?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: That's Henry Gondorff, one of the all-time greats. Not only is he not a manager, he's not even a Negro. That's just makeup. You been had, Macalinski.

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Are you sure it's the same guys?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Positive. I'll never forget those two as long as I live. If I wasn't under indictment, I'd ice 'em myself as soon as the fight's over, which shouldn't be too long now. Macalinski can't believe it. He just sits there in stunne silence.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 186
dialogues.text: A pattern has developed in the fight. Hooker, surprisingl has one advantage. He's faster than Kelley, but Kelley ke coming at him, throwing punch after unch -- jabs, combina tions, round-houses, upper cuts, hooks, eve ing. Hooker is able to dodge three-fourths of them but the one-fourth manage to land are beginning to take a toll.

dialogues.speaker: . LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Looks like Hooker's gettin' ready to go home and spend some of your money. — Whatever doubts Macalinski may have had about Lonnegan's story are now dispelled. His astonishment is turning to cold fury. He turns to two of his bodyguards.

dialogues.speaker: . MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Grimes and Rossavich, get over to that bookie's and get our money back.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: You're wastin' your time. The bookie is probably in with them. He won't even be there.

dialogues.speaker: __MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: {to his men) . Get over there anyvay. And if he is there, bring him with ya. The two goons hustle off. . _. LONNEGAN . Funny, isn't it. You wouldn't think lightning would strike twice like this, I mean, especially with you knowing what happened to me an all. Ab well, I guess we all have our blind spots. | (getting up to go) | Well, I'll be seeing you, Carlo. Sorry I had to be the one to tell you. (turning back) Oh, and Carlo, 1 won't breathe a word of this to anybody. Your secret's good with me. Lonnegan walks off up the aisle, laughing to himself. Macalinski just sits in his chair and steams. curt TO

dialogues.speaker: THE RING AGAIN
dialogues.text: is bobbing and weaving like crazy in an effort to escape Kelley's avalanche of blows. He is able to hit Kelley fro time to time, but whenever he trades with him, he gets th worst of it. Hooker uses everything he knows to protect himself. He clinches, covers up, moves constantly and flurries his way out of corners, but Kelley 15 such a dervish that Hooker is still taking a lot of shots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Kelley traps Hooker ‘in a corner and begins to f away like crazy. Hooker dodges this way and that, but he' getting tag ed and he's unable to get away. A cut opens over his left eye and his legs begin to wobble a little.  190 191 192 193 194 195

dialogues.speaker: AT RINGSIDE 190
dialogues.text: Eirie, The Big Ohio, and Gondorff (who is sitting right b Hooker's corner with Veronica on his arm) yell at Hooker hang in there.

dialogues.speaker: ON HOOKER 191
dialogues.text: He battles back, throwing a wild series of punches. They no damage, but confuse Kelley long enough to let the bel ring.

dialogues.speaker: IN HOOKER'S CORNER OF THE RING 192
dialogues.text: Hooker slumps down on his stool. Eirie immediately gets t sponging him off, as The Big Ohio dabs collodion on the c HOOKER . Jesus, the guy's a goddamn windmill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, Hooker. You're doin' great. Just keep away from him for another round. cuT To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: racing through the city on their way to Chandler's Import Company . cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second round is under way, and once again, Kelley is over Hooker, throwing blows from every conceivable angle. As before, Hooker tries to dance away from the combinatio and dodge the haymakers, but he can't avoid them all and face is turning puffy and red. Soon the cut is open again and he's blinking blood out of his eye. Kelley goes to th body some and begins to raise welts on Hooker's ribs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: crash through the front door, which is locked and into Chandler's office which isn't. :  196 197 198 199 200 201

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strangely enough, the Tuxedo Kid is still there. The goon stick a gun in his face and wave him toward the safe. cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hooker's in trouble as he's slowing down and Kelly is sco more frequently. Kelley connects with three wicked body s and a left to the head that sends Hooker reeling into the ropes. Instead of bouncing away, he just stays there, his legs too tired to move him.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 198
dialogues.text: Even his flurry tactics don't slow Kelley, who wades in a unleashes another barrage. Hooker can do nothing but try weather it. He gives up all pretense to offense. It's pur a matter of survival now.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING
dialogues.text: calls on all the defensive quickness he can muster, movin his head, slowing blows with the forearms and shoulders, ducking, bobbing and leaning back over the ropes. Almost like Ali's rope-a~dope. Kelley, meanwhile, just keeps. banging away, Hooker takes it and takes it and takes it, and finally just sags to the canvas. The count gets to eight and the bell rings.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING
dialogues.text: Eirie and The Big Ohio drag Hooker back to his corner and immediately apply the water and smelling salts, His nose is bleeding as well as his eye, and his chest is heaving. Gondorff comes out of his seat and up to the corner.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: - Lonnegan is loving it.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: Next round oughta be the one. _, FLOYD , . Yeah, looks like Gondorff is tellin' the pretty boy it's time to check out. You think Macalinski's mad enough to kill those guys?

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: I know he's mad enough.  202 203 204 205

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: It's true. He looks like he's ready to eat his seat.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I did it, Gondorff. I went two like you said.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Damn right, Hooker. I'm proud of ya, pal. Now I want you °. out there and knock this guy on butt. - « _HOOKE! What are you talkin' Spout! I'm goin' out there and lie down. This guy can hit.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Not any more you ain't. (pointing into es You recognize that guy about fifteen rows up, fourth seat from the aisle? Hooker looks and finds the man Gondorff is pointing to.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: “in the stands with Floyd.

dialogues.speaker: . HOOKER
dialogues.text: Oh God, it's Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: That's right, and he just told Macalinski that we been connin' him. As a result, Macalinski is ettin! ready" to fi11 all of us ful es.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: How do you know all this?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Haven't got time to lain it now. Look, I don't wanna put the pressure on ya, but if you don't beat this guy, we're all corpses. If Hooker was groggy at the end of the round, he's wide a now.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: But what about Lonnegan? He'll kill us just as fast.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Take my word for it. You win this fight and you won't have to worry . about Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: seThelgtet) You can do it, Hooker. Kelley's gotta be tiring. A guy can only ish out so much punishment. The warning buzzer sounds. Hooker looks around to see Veronica.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER'S POINT OF VIEW
dialogues.text: Veronica's not there any more.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER .
dialogues.text: Hey, what happened to Veronica?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that now. The warning buzzer sounds. The Big Ohio grabs Hooker's he to get his attention.

dialogues.speaker: THE BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: Forget stayin' away from him, Hooker. You gotta start gettin’ some knocks in. He's not gonna hit ya any worse if you trade with him. Hooker nods his head as the bell sounds for round three.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: joyfully anticipating Hooker's demise.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING
dialogues.text: Hooker comes out, and much to Kelley's surprise, doesn't away. Hooker throws a right-left combination and actually lands one. Kelley counters with another swarm of blows, b Hooker stands his ground and comes ripping back. He smash a right to the chest, a left to the ribs and an overhand to the head. The fight is becoming a real slugfest. Kelle headhunting, throwing big haymakers, hooks and uppercuts. Hooker duc ing inside, jolting shots to the ribs and mid- section. Kelley's blows are more spectacularly visible fr even the cheap seats, but Hooker is dishing it out to the body and Kelley is beginning to feel it. Hooker gains mor and more confidence, if nothing else than for the fact he still on his feet, It's turning into a helluva fight, and the crowd is warming to it. All of them expect Lonnegan.

dialogues.speaker: LONNEGAN
dialogues.text: What the hell is goin' on here?

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 211
dialogues.text: Hooker and Kelley are literally toe to toe now, trading punches as fast as their arms can work. One thing is be- coming increasingly clear, however. Kelley is beg nmning tire.” He has trained too little and thrown enough punche for three fights, and he's way behind on motivation. Hook senses it, and now his adrenalin really begins to flow. He's taken Kelley's best shots and Kelly knows it. Hooker rips a left to the stomach and follows with a righ to the side of the head. For the first time in the fight, Kelley begins to backpeddle, looking for a little breathi room.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: One of the goons, Rossovich, returns, a big smile on his He's got the leather bag full of money with him.

dialogues.speaker: _,ROSSAVICH
dialogues.text: The guy was still there. Grimes has got him out in the car. We got nothin’ to worry about. The bet's off. Rossavich doesn't get the show of gratitude out of Macali that he'd expected. At this point, Macalinski is not at a sure he wants that money back. cur TO  214 215 217 218

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 213
dialogues.text: Hooker's really into it now, blasting away with both hand Hooker crowds Kelley and hammers away to the body. Kelley stabs out with his right, but the zip is gone from his punches. He tries to hold on, but Hooker pushes him away, and starts pounding again.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: Lonnegan is speechless. Floyd looks like he's growing hemorrhoids.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 215
dialogues.text: Hooker backs Kelley into a corner, Kelley's punches are j awing the air now. Hooker, walking right through them, ju eeps ripping to the body, occasionally going to the head, but mostly burning up the midsection. This is the first round he's really thrown any punches, so unlike Kelley, h got something left despite the beating he's taken. Kelle rops his guard to protect his aching ribs and Hooker rock him with a right to the chin.

dialogues.speaker: IN HOOKER'S CORNER 216
dialogues.text: Eirie and The Big Ohio are going crazy in the corner. Bir is filling the air with imagina punches in an effort to u Hooker on. He throws one so hard he falls down. Gondorff, of course, has got to maintain his cool, having to preser the fiction that he's being double-crossed, but we know that he's exploding inside.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RING 217
dialogues.text: Hooker pummels away to the stomach again. Kelley's guard comes down and Hooker straightens him up with a wicked up cut that knocks Kelley's mouthpiece clean across the ring Kelley's arms are leaden. This time his guard stays down and his knees begin to sag. Hooker measures him, plants h feet and blasts a right to the nose, a right-left to the and cheekbone, and finally a prodigious uppercut that cat Kelley full on the chin. He wavers a second and pitches f ward on his face.

dialogues.speaker: ON LONNEGAN AND FLOYD IN THE STANDS 218
dialogues.text: Lonnegan leaps out of his seat, his face completely ashen Floyd is too shocked to move. .  ao 219 220 221 222

dialogues.speaker: ON MACALINSKI IN THE STANDS 219
dialogues.text: He has also come out of his seat, a new kind of anger wel up in him. IN THE RING ‘ 220 The referee counts Kelley out and Eirie and The Big Ohio into the ring to embrace Hooker. Hooker tries to dance ar the ring a little, but he's too exhausted. Eirie and Big have to help him out of the ring.

dialogues.speaker: ON MACALINSKI IN THE STANDS 221
dialogues.text: He is on fire.

dialogues.speaker: . GRIMES
dialogues.text: What do we do with Chandler, that bookie guy?

dialogues.speaker: MACALINSKI
dialogues.text: Let him go. Florian and Berrigan were on the level. (with venom) It's Lonnegan that burned us. Cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's general merriment as Eirie, Gondorff and The Big whoop it up, slapping Hooker on the back, tousling his ha etc. Hooker just sorta rolls with it, a thoroughly weary

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Atta boy, Hooker. I knew you could do it!

dialogues.speaker: EIRIE
dialogues.text: (demonstrating with his own awkward punches} You see them combinations, them uppercuts? You were TNT out there tonight, Hooker.

dialogues.speaker: BIG OHIO
dialogues.text: You really showed ‘em what you're made of, Johnny.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Thanks, I hope I never get the chance again.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: If you hurry and get showered, we can still make the ten o'clock train.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Unless Lonnegan's guys are waitin' outside to put a few bullets in us.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Believe me, they're gonna be too busy tryin' to keep Macalinski's guys from puttin' a few bullets in em. cuT TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lonnegan, Floyd and two bodyguards come out of the audito They're in a big hurry and are quite relieved to see thei limousine waiting for them. Floyd opens the back door and Lonnegan slides in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly floyd and the two bodyguards feel the chill of c steel on their spinal columns. Three of Macalinski's men are holding .38's in their backs. Two others slide in nex to the unsuspecting Lonnegan and close the doors. Lonnega getting the same treatment he gave Kid Twist. His face is frozen in terror as the limousine drives off to keep his with the cement cobbler. cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The proprietor is closing up for the night, totaling up h receipts. Snyder and his eight fellow agents enter the st They tell the man to continue what he's doing as the two agents hide behind the counter and the others go into the meat locker. The Chinaman goes about his business with no hint of concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pick up Hooker, Eirie, Gondorff, The Big Ohio and the Tuxedo Kid coming out another exit of the auditorium. The Big Ohio and the Tuxedo Kid climb into a car driven by Singleton. Gondorff, Hooker and Eirie pile into one drive by Billie. As the cars pull out, we: : cur To  227 228 229

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snydex and his men are all in place now, hiding behind various boxes and crates, their guns drawn, ready for act cur To

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gondorff, Hooker, Eirie and Billie driving through the ci in their car. :

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: {to Gondorff) So you knew all along what Lonnegan was doin', didn't ya?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Yeah, once I found out Lonnegan killed Twist and pinned it on Macalinski, I figured it from there. I had a little help with some of the details though.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: From who?

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: Veronica. Both Hooker and Eirie are stunned. GONDORFF . I sent her up to Chicago to get next to Lonnegan the year I went into the pen. I knew he'd come after us as soon as I got out, so I figured I better have somebody watchin' him. Lonnegan hired her right away ‘cause he figured she'd be a great way to Keep an eye on us. He was the one that told her to get next to you. She tipped me off on everything she could, but she didn't find out about Twist until it was too late. This is all a little much for Hooker. He just slumps back in his seat in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snyder and his men are still waiting, crouched in antici- pation. A couple of them are getting a little restless.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: You sure they're comin' here?

dialogues.speaker: SNYDER
dialogues.text: Shut up, will ya. Of course I'm sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: has recovered enough to speak.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: Veronica. Jesus, why didn't ya tell me? All that hootchie-kootchie she was puttin’ out was part of the act. I mean she's givin' me these raven eyes and....

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: I never heard about no hootchie- kootchie and I don't want to. I woulda told ya she was in on the ground floor, but I didn't want ya to get too friendly with her. Babes and griftin' don't mix. I didn't know you were gonna go and get stuck on her anyway.

dialogues.speaker: HOOKER
dialogues.text: I'm not stuck on her. I just don't like playin' the patsy.

dialogues.speaker: GONDORFF
dialogues.text: You oughta thank her for one thing. She helped Lonnegan get Snyder off your back. The car comes to a stop and Gondorff and the others get o We can't tell from the angle exactly where they are. cut TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a noise at the door and all the agents spring int readiness. The door opens and one man walks in. The agent spring from their cover and surround him, gone leveled. O turns on the lights to reveal a little Delivery Boy with bouquet of flowers.

dialogues.speaker: DELIVERY BOY
dialogues.text: There a guy named Snyder here?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED 231
dialogues.text: Before Snyder can answer, one of the agents reads the car on the bouquet.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Dear Snyder. Sorry we couldn't make it. Start the party without us. Love, Henry Gondorff. All the agents turn and focus their undying contempt on S a man who seems destined always to be in the right place wrong time. Right now, Snyder looks like he's gonna be il cur TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
